Join Andrew Reiner, Jeff Cork, Dan Ryckert, and myself as we reminisce on our experiences with it and Dan still tries to make sense of Sin. Later we continue the JRPG fandom and take a look at title that's sure to be a blast from the past.

secondSegmentGames: Tweety's Hearty Party (トゥイーティーのハーティーパーティー)

article.title: Replay – Primal
article.author: Dan Ryckert
content: Back in 2003, Sony's Cambridge studio had the opportunity to develop an ambitious action game after working on the MediEvil series. Primal was the result, and it follows a girl as she searches for her rock star boyfriend throughout many otherworldly realms.
Join Andrew Reiner, Tim Turi, and myself as we meet the gargoyle Scree and listen to him exhaust us with lore that we don't give a crap about.

secondSegmentGames: Strawberry Shortcake: The Sweet Dreams Game

article.title: Replay – Star Wars: Bounty Hunter
article.author: Andrew Reiner
content: When I was constructing my Fall of the Empire editorial, I spent many days and nights looking back at LucasArts' catalog of games, fondly remember the hits and cringing at the mountain of missteps made by this studio. The research I did for the canceled title Star Wars: 1313 led me into Game Informer's vault to locate LucasArts' other Fett-centric title, Star Wars: Bounty Hunter. Star Wars: 1313 was going to place players into the armor of Boba Fett. Star Wars: Bounty Hunter focuses on Boba's father, Jango. In this week's episode of Replay, we take a look at Bounty Hunter and discuss numerous Star Wars topics, going well out of our way to anger fans of George Lucas' galaxy far, far away.
The second segment takes a look at a licensed property that probably shouldn't have been transformed into a video game.

mainSegmentGamesAdv.title: Xena: Warrior Princess: Talisman of Fate

article.title: Replay – Xena: Warrior Princess
article.author: Andrew Reiner
content: In the fall of 1999, Renaissance Pictures' Xena: Warrior Princess made an unexpected splash in video games. This show, which followed the battle-hardened warrior Xena on her quest to redeem her past sins, caught the eye of two game publishers. Electronic Arts struck first. Teaming with developer Vivendi Universal, Electronic Arts released a hack n' slash adventure game based on the show on September 30 for PlayStation and Game Boy Color. Game Informer critic Matt Helgeson gave this Chakram-throwing experience a fair grade, comparing it to the wacky Rising Zan: Samurai Gunman. A few months after this game hit the market, Titus Software release Xena: Warrior Princess – Talisman of Fate, a fighting game for Nintendo 64 that...well...you'll just have to see for yourself.
We take a look at both of these games in an extended episode or Replay. After watching these two games, stick around for a third segment.

episodeTitle: Replay: Iron Man and X-O Manowar in Heavy Metal

mainSegmentGamesAdv.title: Iron Man and X-O Manowar in Heavy Metal

external_links.title: Replay: Iron Man and X-O Manowar in Heavy Metal
Replay: Iron Man and X-O Manowar in Heavy Metal

article.title: Replay – Iron Man And X-O Manowar In Heavy Metal
article.author: Andrew Reiner
content: The game title is not a mistake. Marvel Comics' famed Avenger Iron Man is teaming up with the lesser-known, hot dog-armed Valiant Comics hero X-O Manowar. Their mission? To protect a nuclear power plant in St. Paul, MN. Game Informer cohort Joe Juba and I do our best to thwart this invasion, but, well...you'll see what happens. I think you'll agree that more games need a high-five button. Iron Man and X-O Manowar in Heavy Metal launched on PlayStation, Saturn, Game Boy, Game Gear, and PC in 1996. We take a look at the PlayStation version.
Our second segment takes a look at a game that is even worse than Heavy Metal, if you can believe that. Sit back and enjoy our pain, Replay viewers!

article.title: Replay – Tenchu: Stealth Assassins
article.author: Dan Ryckert
content: When you think of stealth games in 1998, it's understandable if the first title that comes to mind is Metal Gear Solid. That said, another well-received stealth game released less than a week before it. Activision published Tenchu: Stealth Assassins on August 31, 1998, and it allowed gamers to take out enemies with a variety of ninja tricks.
How does the stealth action hold up 16 years later? Watch below to see Andrew Reiner, Joe Juba, and myself test out our sneaking skills.

article.title: Replay – Tail Concerto
article.author: Andrew Reiner
content: On this week's episode of Replay, the Game Informer gang has a hard time identifying cats and dogs in CyberConnect2's PlayStation title, Tail Concerto. Suiting up as a police officer named Waffle, we check out the opening moments of this adventure, battling numerous cats (could be dogs?) along the way. Our journey ends with a lengthy boss battle. If you're a fan of Capcom's Mega Man Legends series, you'll want to take a look at this title.

And as always, we're including a second segment with this Replay in which we take a look at another game. Enjoy the episode, folks, and please let us know if you think Waffle is a cat or dog in the comments section below.

mainSegmentGamesAdv.title: Gargoyle's Quest II: The Demon Darkness

article.title: Replay – Gargoyle's Quest Series
article.author: Tim Turi
content: This week we take a look at a few overlooked spin-offs from Capcom's hard as nails Ghost 'n' Goblins series. These three titles feature the infamous Firebrand, a flying gargoyle usually known for knocking the armor off Arthur in the blink of an eye. We shake up the standard Replay formula by checking out the entire series of Nintendo titles featuring the little red demon.
Join Andrew Reiner, Jeff Cork, Dan Ryckert, and myself as we play Gargoyle's Quest on the Game Boy, Gargoyle's Quest II on the NES, and the third entry Demon's Crest on the SNES.

article.title: Replay – Ico
article.author: Dan Ryckert
content: Few titles in recent memory are as revered as Ico and Shadow of the Colossus. With gorgeous visuals, striking atmospheres, and solid gameplay, they're both considered classics of the PS2 era for good reason. We may be a ways away from hearing concrete information about Team Ico's next title, but that's not stopping us from revisiting their first.
Watch below to see Andrew Reiner, Tim Turi, Ben Hanson, and myself head back to the gorgeous world of Ico.

article.title: Replay – The Getaway
article.author: Dan Ryckert
content: One of the more ambitious titles of the PS2 era was Team Soho's The Getaway. Featuring large recreations of London and tons of voice acting, its planned release at the console's launch was significantly delayed. It finally released in January of 2003, and we're revisiting it over ten years later.
Watch below to see the Replay crew take to the streets of London.

article.title: Replay – Advent Rising
article.author: Dan Ryckert
content: One of Majesco's most ambitious titles was 2005's Advent Rising, which featured a script from science fiction author Orson Scott Card. Originally planned to be a trilogy, the game also featured a comic book tie-in and planned PSP title. Sales fell short of expectations, which is why we only have one entry in the (planned) series to revisit for Replay.
Watch below to see the Replay crew tackle the Majesco flop.

article.title: Replay – Dead Man's Hand
article.author: Dan Ryckert
content: Many games tried to bring the Old West to the gaming world, but few really nailed it until Red Dead Redemption. One of the attempts was 2004's Dead Man's Hand from Human Head Studios, and it's the subject of this week's episode of Replay.
Click below to watch Andrew Reiner, Tim Turi, intern Isaac Perry, and myself test our gunslinging abilities before venturing into a new second segment.

article.title: Replay – Catwoman
article.author: Dan Ryckert
content: Catwoman is a pretty cool character, and she's been played well in the past by actresses like Michelle Pfeiffer, Anne Hathaway, Julie Newmar, and Lee Meriwether. While Halle Berry is certainly a talented actress as well, her version of the DC Comics character is universally derided. Good thing they made a video game based on that awful movie!
Click below to watch Tim Turi take control of the feline, while Andrew Reiner, myself, and news editor Mike Futter watch on.

article.title: Replay – Jurassic Park
article.author: Andrew Reiner
content: You: "Wait, didn't this game come out a couple of years ago?" Us: "It sure did! And thanks to the arrival of PlayStation 4 and Xbox One, we can now dive into PlayStation 3 and Xbox 360's libraries for Replay game choices. Complain all you want. These are the rules! And we didn't make them up (actually we did)."

Don't worry, we won't be visiting this well often over the course of the next couple of years. We have plenty of long forgotten and classic games from earlier generations to get to first. This week, we just wanted to show you that this generation is now an option for us. We also picked a game that is terrible and hasn't gotten much exposure. In many ways, this stinky visit to Jurassic Park paved the way for Telltale's excellent The Walking Dead series. Look for the similarities and keep your eyes peeled for dinos hiding in the brush!

article.title: Replay – Super Mario Galaxy
article.author: Dan Ryckert
content: With the recent release of Super Mario 3D World, Nintendo fans are up to their ears once again in fire flowers, Goombas, and Koopa Troopas. Many of us have been having a blast with the game, and it made us remember how incredible Super Mario Galaxy was when it released in 2007. Considering its level of quality and relatively recent release, we assume that the platformer holds up fine six years later. We put that assumption to the test in this week's episode of Replay.
Click below to see Andrew Reiner, Tim Turi, Joe Juba, and myself go back to the star-collecting, planet-hopping adventure.

article.title: Replay – Toy Commander
article.author: Andrew Reiner
content: Odds are you've never seen Godzilla wearing a bunny outfit, unless you played No Cliché's excellent Dreamcast title Toy Commander. We take a look at this charming game in this week's episode with special guest and Replay sensation Aram Jabbari. Our adventure takes us to a cat's litter box as we search for sugar cubes, and to the dangerous streets of a cardboard town. We usually suck at playing games on Replay, but today, we look like the best damn toy players ever.
Stick around for our second segment, which takes a look at another long-forgotten game.

article.title: Replay – Neo Contra
article.author: Dan Ryckert
content: We didn't know exactly what to expect when we pulled Neo Contra off the shelf in the Vault. If we had to guess, we'd probably assume it was an ill-fated 3D reboot of the classic co-op series. What we didn't expect was one of the crazier action games we've played in a while, and it led to a very wild episode of Replay.
Watch below to see Jeff Marchiafava and Tim Turi team up as Andrew Reiner and myself cheer them on. Be sure to stick around for a similarly crazy second segment.

article.title: Replay – Panzer Dragoon
article.author: Ben Reeves
content: Panzer Dragoon was one of the Sega Saturn's launch titles here in the U.S. It also happens to be one of the finest video games ever crafted by human hands. But how has the title aged? Flawlessly. Don't believe us? Check it out for yourself.
Watch Jeff Cork, Andrew Reiner, Ben Reeves, and Bryan Vore fire polygons out of the air using the mouth lasers of a dragoon.

episodeTitle: Replay: Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: The Hyperstone Heist

external_links.title: Replay: Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: The Hyperstone Heist
Replay: Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: The Hyperstone Heist

article.title: Replay – Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: The Hyperstone Heist
article.author: Bryan Vore
content: Despite the ongoing console wars amongst consumers, most multiplatform games in the same generation are basically identical. Back in the Super Nintendo versus Sega Genesis days, games would always be at least a little bit off from each other due to hardware differences. In some cases (Shadowrun for example) games would share a title and that was about it. In this episode of Replay we take on Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: The Hyperstone Heist, a remix of Turtles in Time, the original Turtles arcade game, and a few completely new elements.

Tim Turi leads Bryan Vore and Andrew Reiner through one of his favorite brawlers and we try to spot the differences from the more well-known Turtles games. See if we can make it through the entire game in one sitting!

article.title: Replay – Target: Terror
article.author: Dan Ryckert
content: Even if the Wii didn't become the shooter destination that Nintendo fans initially claimed it would be, it proved on rare occasions that it could be good for some silly shootouts (The House of the Dead: Overkill immediately comes to mind). One insane game apparently flew beneath our radar, and I couldn't be happier that I spotted it in the Game Informer vault. We played Target: Terror for this week's episode of Replay, and it's just awesome.
Watch below to see Tim Turi, Andrew Reiner, Jeff Cork, and myself protect America from those that would harm her.

article.title: Replay – Omikron: The Nomad Soul
article.author: Kimberley Wallace
content: Update: Today we remember musician David Bowie, who passed away today after an 18-month battle with cancer. Bowie's influence has been felt in games, with his music appearing in Elite Beat Agents and, more recently, Metal Gear Solid V: The Phantom Pain.

He also touched the gaming world with Quantic Dream's first game, Omikron: The Nomad Soul. Bowie participated in the development and starred in it, creating a unique experience that laid the groundwork for David Cage's later games, including Heavy Rain and Beyond: Two Souls.
If you're interested in checking this out for yourself, it's available for $9.99 on Steam and GoG.
Originally published October 13, 2013

Long before he cast Ellen Page in Beyond: Two Souls and created the Origami Killer in Heavy Rain, David Cage worked with famed musician David Bowie in Omikron: The Nomad Soul. While we never played as Ziggy Stardust as we moved from body to body, you can follow the misadventures of myself, Dan, Jeff Cork, and Reiner in David Cage's first game at Quantic Dream.

We ended up in the Dreamcast version of Omikron, which features better fighting segments, but worse FPS-style combat than its PC counterpart. Omikron hasn't aged particularly well, and it's obvious Cage has grown as a game designer, but that doesn't take anything away from the unique concepts presented here.

article.title: Replay – Strider
article.author: Jeff Cork
content: Fighting-game fans probably recognize Strider Hiryu from the Marvel vs. Capcom games, but they might not be as familiar with his origins. The sword-slashing hero debuted in the 1989 arcade game Strider, which was later ported to the Genesis. Join Dan, Tim, Reiner, and me as we wage a one-man war against a red army of robotic enemies.

We played the arcade version for this Replay, which was part of a PSOne Strider collection. It's clear that the game was designed to take your money, and it did its job nicely. Let's just say that we would have left the arcade several dollars' poorer if we'd been paying to play. Be sure to stick around for the Roulette for a look at a not-quite classic.

article.title: Replay – Die Hard Arcade
article.author: Dan Ryckert
content: Earlier this year, we became enamored with a wacky Dreamcast title called Dynamite Cop. Its predecessor also made it stateside, although it came under the name of Die Hard Arcade. You won't find many real ties to the awesome action series, however, and the protagonist looks nothing like Bruce Willis. What it does have is plenty more ridiculous brawls and silly interactive cutscenes.
Watch below to see Andrew Reiner, Jeff Cork, Jason Oestricher, and myself dive into this Saturn title.

episodeTitle: Replay: The Legend of Zelda: The Wind Waker

mainSegmentGamesAdv.title: The Legend of Zelda: The Wind Waker

description: The Legend of Zelda: The Wind Waker is the featured game in the one hundred ninety-sixth installment of Replay. It is one of the few games given a Perfect 10.

external_links.title: Replay: The Legend of Zelda: The Wind Waker
Replay: The Legend of Zelda: The Wind Waker

article.title: Replay – The Legend Of Zelda: The Wind Waker
article.author: Dan Ryckert
content: With Link's GameCube adventure heading to the Wii U thanks to The Wind Waker HD, we decided it was time to hit the high seas in the original. This polarizing entry in the long-running series introduced a dramatic shift in art style and plenty of sailing, and you'll see it in this week's episode.
Watch below to see Andrew Reiner, Ben Reeves, Jason Oestricher, and myself return to the flooded world of Hyrule.

episodeTitle: Replay: Star Wars Episode I: Jedi Power Battles

mainSegmentGamesAdv.title: Star Wars Episode I: Jedi Power Battles

external_links.title: Replay: Star Wars Episode I: Jedi Power Battles
Replay: Star Wars Episode I: Jedi Power Battles

article.title: Replay – Jedi Power Battles
article.author: Adam Biessener
content: In honor of my time with Game Informer coming to a close, the crew let me pick the Replay this week – and for some reason I took pity on staff and viewer alike by not picking some obscure hardcore PC strategy game from the '80s.

Jedi Power Battles is a surprisingly good co-op brawler from the depths of the dark era of Episode I madness. The PSone 3D graphics are of course rough on modern eyes, but the gameplay holds up much better...at least when you're not literally stuck between Jar Jar and an oncoming hovertank. I played an obnoxious amount of this game (after my second time through Lunar: Silver Star Story Complete) one summer at an overnight job where I could play PlayStation games on a tiny 13-inch TV. At least the pixels weren't quite so obvious on that crappy little box.
The Roulette this week is another Star Wars game from the same era, and it too surprises in its failure to suck -- even if it's no X-Wing vs. TIE Fighter.
Thanks for watching and for everything else over the years, everyone.

article.title: Replay – Sonic 3 & Knuckles
article.author: Andrew Reiner
content: One of Replay's founding fathers has been absent for a while. His name is Tim Turi, and he misses being on this show. Due to a busy travel schedule in recent weeks, we haven't been able to line up our schedules to include him in Replay episodes. While he was gone, he was upset to learn that we recorded two episodes that normally would have involved him. He's long been a fan of Castlevania: Symphony of the Night, and he traditionally plays all of our survival horror-themed games, like last week's Illbleed Replay Roulette. To make it up to our rock-climbing, veggie-eating friend, we are dedicating this week's episode to him.
We have a couple of surprises planned for him. Watch us play Sonic 3 & Knuckles in the video below, and help us pay tribute to Tim Turi in the comments section below.

description: This episode's Roulette, Illbleed, later became a Super Replay.

article.title: Replay – Jet Grind Radio
article.author: Dan Ryckert
content: "Cel shading" is a term that's been tossed around frequently for over a decade, but gamers in the 90s had never heard of the unique graphical style. With the 2000 release of Jet Grind Radio, the style that would go on to be used in The Legend of Zelda: The Wind Waker and many more games was popularized.

How does the goofy, graffiti-stained title hold up thirteen years later? Check it out below in the new episode of Replay, complete with a Roulette segment that some of our bigger fans have been calling for for quite some time.

episodeTitle: Replay: Castlevania: Symphony of the Night

external_links.title: Replay: Castlevania: Symphony of the Night
Replay: Castlevania: Symphony of the Night

article.title: Replay – Castlevania: Symphony Of The Night
article.author: Dan Ryckert
content: Castlevania: Symphony of the Night is one of my top ten games of all time, and I've wanted to take it down to the Replay room for some time now. That's why I got so excited when Reiner came by my desk to let me know that it was this week's episode. Alucard's 1997 adventure is a classic that plays as well today as it did 16 years ago, and is considered by most to be the best entry in the series.
Once you're done with Symphony of the Night, stick around for an import game in a new Reported segment.

article.title: Replay – Destroy All Humans!
article.author: Tim Turi
content: Players of The Bureau: XCOM Declassified will soon be busy blasting aliens in the 1950s, but what about extraterrestrial sympathizers who want to experience the other side of the invasion? Pandemic's PlayStation 2 and Xbox game Destroy All Humans! delivers that experience with a humorous, satirical tone complete with anal probe guns, tractor beams, and mind control. We take the last-gen open world sci-fi game for a spin.
Join Andrew Reiner, Jason Oestreicher, Ben Reeves, Joe Juba, and myself as we dust off Crypto's UFO and take it through the countryside and raise hell at a county fair.

article.title: Replay – Nightmare Creatures
article.author: Kyle Hilliard
content: Nightmare Creatures is a solid PlayStation-era action title with gameplay that has aged very well, even if its visuals haven't.

Join Andrew Reiner, Ben Reeves, Jeff Marchiafava, and myself as we try to make through the game without shutting it off in sheer terror. Make sure to stick around for the Replay Roulette to hear Ben Reeves shout things like, "Boom boom!", "Welcome to boom-town!" and the classic, "Boomerang!"

article.title: Replay – Mr. Bones
article.author: Dan Ryckert
content: Whenever I've stumbled into the Saturn section of the Game Informer Vault, my eye always tends to catch the box for Mr. Bones. I've pulled it out on many occasions, wondering what the hell this game with a guitar-playing skeleton would be like. Thanks to this week's Replay, I have to wonder no more.
Watch below to see Andrew Reiner, Tim Turi, Jeff Cork, and myself take on the quirky Saturn platformer.

secondSegmentGames: Congo the Movie: The Lost City of Zinj

article.title: Replay – Shadowrun
article.author: Andrew Reiner
content: With the release of the first Shadowrun RPG in nearly 20 years, Game Informer's office is abuzz with excitement over this beloved series. Rather than just talking about our memories of the Super Nintendo Shadowrun title, we pulled the game out of our vault to test our memory of the early minutes of the game.

Although I played the game religiously when I was young, my memory of it wasn't as sharp as I had hoped. Come see how I fare, as Matt Miller, Jeff Cork, and Tim Turi try to help me out. Stick around for a very special second segment that you all wanted to see after listening to Game Informer's "bad game" podcast. Hint: It involves two-headed snakes and sentient totems.

article.title: Replay – Mansion Of Hidden Souls
article.author: Dan Ryckert
content: In 1993, pre-rendered video was all the rage. It didn't control well, but it sure did look like the future at one point in time. Mansion of Hidden Souls is a Saturn title that attempted to join the craze, and it's aged terribly. You can see it for yourself in this week's episode of Replay.
Check out more episodes at our Replay hub.

description: Second Sight is the title game of the one hundred eighty-sixth episode of Replay. The Replay Roulette for this episode is Worms Armageddon.
The host of this episode is Joe Juba and features Andrew Reiner, Tim Turi, and Kim Wallace. Tim plays the featured game and everyone plays the Roulette.
notes: Reiner introduced the Roulette as being a new segment where competitive games are played among the host and featured guests.
This is another instance of the featured game being on a different console than the Roulette game. In this case Second Sight is on PlayStation 2 while Worms Armageddon is on PlayStation.
The tutorial of Second Sight was skipped in favor of starting the main part of the game. Most of the time Replays begin with the beginning of a game, tutorial and all.
Joe reviewed Second Sight in the September 2004 issue of Game Informer and gave the game an 8.5 out of 10.
"You won’t find as many staggeringly awesome moments as Psi-Ops, but it is certainly an inventive and unique stealth game in its own right."[1]
Reiner provided the "Second Opinion" review and scored it 7.5 out of 10.
"All told, however, Second Sight is the very definition of mediocrity."[1]
quotes: Second Sight
Joe: "Did you see that poor guy explode? It was great." Tim: "I certainly did, Joe."
Tim: "Radley Scitt's Ahhhliens."
Reiner: "It's from putting your hands in poop and then putting them in your eyes right?"
Joe: "I side with whatever route shows me gorillas."
Reiner: "Uh-oh. This is very Cyberia-esque, Tim."

Joe: "Shut up four-eyes."
