article.title: Replay – Second Sight
article.author: Joe Juba
content: When it comes to last-gen psionic action, Midway's Psi-Ops is the preeminent example. However, Codemasters released a title with a similar premise in the same year. Second Sight combines gunplay and supernatural powers, along with a hefty amount of stealth and storytelling.

How does Second Sight stack up to its competition? Join us as we find out. Andrew Reiner, Joe Juba, Tim Turi, and Kim Wallace delve into this little-celebrated adventure from Timesplitters developer Free Radical. You can also get some free advice on how to name your giant, evil medical research company.
After the psychic action, stick around for a brand new second segment!

article.title: Replay – Total Overdose
article.author: Dan Ryckert
content: Back in 2005, Deadline Games and Eidos released a ridiculous action title that rarely gets talked about anymore. Total Overdose is a Mexican shoot-em-up in the style of Robert Rodriguez films, and features a wide variety of insane abilities. It's also this week's Replay.
Watch below to see Andrew Reiner, Jeff Marchiafava, Ben Reeves, and myself clean up the cartels with guns blazing.

episodeTitle: Replay: Indiana Jones And The Emperor's Tomb

mainSegmentGamesAdv.title: Indiana Jones And The Emperor's Tomb

external_links.title: Replay: Indiana Jones and the Emperor's Tomb
Replay: Indiana Jones and the Emperor's Tomb

article.title: Replay – Indiana Jones And The Emperor's Tomb
article.author: Tim Turi
content: The closest we've ever come to playing an Indiana Jones game on Replay is Donald Duck's treasure-hunting adventure, Quackshot. While Quackshot is one of the best Genesis games, we thought it was time to check in on one of Indy's less celebrated adventures, Indiana Jones and the Emperor's Tomb for the Xbox and PS2. Watch us climb ruins like Lara Croft and show off Indy's whip-wielding skills.

The conversation between Matt Bertz, Andrew Reiner, Joe Juba, and I eventually wanders to the topics of the Indiana Jones films and the future of video games based on other Lucas franchises. Stick around for the return of a very special segment with a surprisingly intense finale.

article.title: Replay – Spy Fiction
article.author: Dan Ryckert
content: Long before Deadly Premonition aped Twin Peaks, Swery took a shot at his own version of Metal Gear Solid. Spy Fiction didn't sell well, but it's fondly remembered in some pockets of gamers for its quirky take on stealth action. We decided to take a look at this piece of Swery's early work for Replay.
Click below to watch Andrew Reiner, Kyle Hilliard, Jeff Cork, and myself take on Spy Fiction.

article.title: Replay – Shadow Hearts
article.author: Kimberley Wallace
content: In December of 2001, a new RPG series hit the scene for PlayStation 2, entitled Shadow Hearts. With its Lovecraftian horror and distorted take on historical events and characters, the franchise was a unique, dark, and unpredictable. In this episode of Replay, we take a look the first Shadow Hearts, the entry that brought us protagonist Yuri Hyuga and his quest to protect exorcist Alice Elliot.

Since the franchise is very near and dear to my heart, I've been waiting to show it off to my fellow staffers. Unfortunately, it doesn't go completely as planned. Watch below as Andrew Reiner, Joe Juba, Dan Ryckert, and I react to how Yuri's love for Alice began. Also stick around to see an awesome roulette pick by our very own video producer Jason Oestreicher. Get ready to see some crazy things. After all, we have Joe Juba and Dan Ryckert in the same room, and they make an announcement.

article.title: Replay – The Punisher
article.author: Dan Ryckert
content: Years before Arkham Asylum blew Batman fans away with its treatment of the character, Volition attempted to give a similar treatment to The Punisher. While it wasn't a massive success, it's hard to deny that the game captures the spirit of the hyper-violent revenge story. We decided to revisit the Saints Row developer's PS2 title for this week's Replay.
Watch below to see Andrew Reiner, Jeff Cork, Bryan Vore, and myself seek revenge.

article.title: Replay – Jet Force Gemini
article.author: Kyle Hilliard
content: After Rare gave Donkey Kong his own game and crafted a 3D model of Pierce Brosnan for Goldeneye, the developer made a cinematic sci-fi shooter called Jet Force Gemini.

It was the true start of the popular helmeted-space-soldier-alien-shooter motif nearly two years before Halo released on the Xbox. Jet Force Gemini was an innovative game in many ways, with optional surround sound audio, widescreen presentation, and a story with three simultaneous narratives occurring across different locations around the universe. You might be able to count the frame rate on one hand, but when it released right at the end of the Nintendo 64's life, it was a fairly impressive adventure.
This week's Replay Roulette is also very exciting, with a game that had some very strange localization choices.

article.title: Replay – Body Harvest
article.author: Jeff Cork
content: Grand Theft Auto III was the first entry in the series to feature a 3D open world, but it wasn't the first time that the development team tackled the concept. That honor goes to the N64 game Body Harvest, which DMA Design released three years before GTA III. Watch as Reiner, Dan, Tim, and I go on a bug hunt and learn a thing or two about maps.

Body Harvest was a long-delayed game that featured a hero who could battle buglike invaders on foot or in a variety of vehicles. It hasn't aged particularly well, but it was ridiculously ambitious for the time (1998) Our adventure meanders a bit, thanks in part to a few issues with the game's navigation system (Tim was on the sticks!). As bad as we thought the UI was in Body Harvest, it did little to prepare us for the roulette game. That one's an indecipherable mess that must be seen to be believed.

article.title: Replay – 24: The Game
article.author: Dan Ryckert
content: Earlier this week, I saw Game Informer reviews editor Joe Juba jump up and do a little dance around the office. The reason? He had just read a headline stating that action drama 24 will be returning for a ninth season. Reiner and myself started talking to him about the insane adventures of Jack Bauer, and instantly realized that we were both really excited for its return as well. After that conversation, the focus of our next episode of Replay was apparent.
Our opinions on the game may differ, but that didn't stop us from getting into plenty of silly 24 talk. Check out the new episode below.

article.title: Replay – Onimusha: Warlords
article.author: Ben Reeves
content: Capcom's Onimusha series took real life characters from history and retold actual historical battles with supernatural elements. The game follows a couple of ghost busting Samurai who travel through the country killing demonic monsters and absorbing their souls with a mystical gauntlet. It's probably pretty close to the actual history.

Watch Game Informer editors Tim Turi, Andrew Reiner, Jason Oestreicher, and Ben Reeves tackle the opening chapters of Capcom's action/survival horror series, solve a few chest puzzles, and stab a lot of dudes on the ground.

article.title: Replay – Dinosaurs For Hire
article.author: Andrew Reiner
content: A long-time Replay viewer suggested we take a look at Dinosaurs for Hire, a Sega Genesis title based on the short-lived Malibu Comic book series of the same name. We're going to have to listen to our viewership more often. Seeing dinosaurs as protagonists in a Contra-like sidescroller is as fascinating and weird as it sounds.

We played more of this game than we probably should have, and probably could have turned this episode into a full-on Super Replay if we kept going. Watch as a stegosaurus and triceratops unload assault rifle rounds into ninjas, robots, and giant skyscaper-bound monstrosities.
We hope you all are having a great Saturday morning! Enjoy the episode and we'll see you again in seven days!

description: Jurassic Park: Trespasser is the name of the 175th episode of Replay. It was posted on the Game Informer website on April 27th 2013. The Replay Roulette  for this episode is Heavy Metal: Geomatrix.
This episode is hosted by Andrew Reiner and features Dan Ryckert , Ben Hanson and Tim Turi. Jason Oestreicher handles video and technical duty.
Jurassic Park: Trespasser was Dan Ryckert's pick for the 2013 Super Replay Showdown, and has been mentioned previously on Replay Episodes, notably on the  Half-Life Super Replay.

article.title: Replay – Jurassic Park: Trespasser
article.author: Dan Ryckert
content: In this year's Super Replay Showdown, the game I was fighting for was arguably the worst of the bunch. I had heard stories of the insane and hilarious physics of Jurassic Park: Trespasser, and the whole boob tattoo health meter sounded ridiculous. Despite hearing these stories on several occasions, I had never met anyone that actually played it. I may have lost the Super Replay Showdown, but that didn't stop me from lobbying for Trespasser as a standard episode of Replay.
Watch below to see Andrew Reiner, Tim Turi, Ben Hanson, and I give a test run to one of the most awkward games I've ever played.

article.title: Replay – Earthbound
article.author: Kyle Hilliard
content: Earthbound is finally coming to the Wii U's Virtual Console, but we refused to wait any longer to play Nintendo's quirky RPG classic again, so we dove into our vault and took it for a nostalgic spin.

Join three Earthbound fans (Jeff Cork, Kyle Hilliard, and Kimberley Wallace), and one person who just thought the game was 'okay' (Andrew Reiner), as they pick their favorite foods, find out a secret about Jeff Cork's past, and how best to take advantage of an AOL account in the nineties. Also, make sure to stick around after Earthbound for a segment we haven't done in awhile with a very strange game.

article.title: Replay – Eternal Darkness
article.author: Dan Ryckert
content: A few weeks ago, we asked the Overblood/Replay Facebook community what they'd like to see for a Replay. We let them organize the poll and vote among themselves, and the winner was the fondly-remembered Eternal Darkness for Gamecube.
Watch below to see Tim Turi, Andrew Reiner, Jeff Cork, and myself attempt to keep our sanity meters full while playing this spooky title.

external_links.title: Replay: The X-Files: Resist or Serve
Replay: The X-Files: Resist or Serve

article.title: Replay – The X-Files: Resist Or Serve
article.author: Dan Ryckert
content: Licensed titles have seen a spotty history throughout console generations, The Playstation 2 era was filled with many mediocre-to-terrible titles like 24, The Sopranos: Road To Respect, Reservoir Dogs, Scarface, and plenty more. Another licensed title that didn't exactly set the world on fire is The X-Files: Resist or Serve, and we're playing it this week for Replay.
Watch below to see Tim Turi, Andrew Reiner, Joe Juba, and myself relive the adventures of Mulder and Scully.

article.title: Replay – Corpse Killer
article.author: Dan Ryckert
content: Back in the mid-90s, FMV games were destined to become the future of the industry. Consoles were technically capable of presenting actual images of people and environments, so why would any sucker go back to boring old sprites and polygons? Well, it turns out that being limited to actual footage limits gameplay to an excruciating degree. We learned this quickly when we booted up 1994's Corpse Killer for Sega Saturn.
Watch below to see us mow down hordes of the pixellated undead in this awful title. Be sure to stick around afterwards to see the finals of this year's Super Replay Showdown!

article.title: Replay – Thief: The Dark Project
article.author: Ben Reeves
content: In the mid '90s, Looking Glass Studios innovated on the FPS genre by creating a slow-placed stealth game fraught with tension. The game won numerous awards and was praised by critics, but does this innovative title still hold up a decade and a half later? We find out.
Watch Andrew Reiner, Ben Hanson, Dan Ryckert, and I stumble through one of Thief's early levels. Then stay tuned as the final four duke it our in our Replay Showdown.

description: Robotoki president Robert Bowling joins this episode as a guest.

article.title: Replay – Akuji The Heartless (Guest: Robert Bowling)
article.author: Dan Ryckert
content: Crystal Dynamics is best known for their work on Tomb Raider, Legacy of Kain, and Gex. One of their Playstation titles is rarely talked about when discussing the company's history, and that's the action platformer Akuji the Heartless. We were curious to revisit the title to see if it was an underappreciated gem, so we picked it for this week's Replay.
Click below to watch Andrew Reiner, Tim Turi, Robotoki president Robert Bowling, and myself take control of Akuji for the first time in over a decade.

article.title: Replay – Parasite Eve
article.author: Kimberley Wallace
content: In this episode of Replay, we take a trek with the famed Aya Brea from Parasite Eve.

A PS1 horror/RPG hybrid, Parasite Eve made its mark with its strong female lead and backdrop of New York City. In the video below, we take a look at the opening. Yes, that includes the infamous opera scene. So sit back, relax, and join host Andrew Reiner, Ben Reeves, Dan Ryckert, and myself as we explore why operas aren't always boring.

article.title: Replay – Deadly Creatures
article.author: Dan Ryckert
content: One of the most unique Wii titles revolved around a spider, a scorpion, and actors Billy Bob Thornton and the late Dennis Hopper. THQ released Deadly Creatures in 2009 to little fanfare, but many that played it were charmed by its quirkiness. This week, we see if that charm holds up.

Be sure to stick around for the second segment, in which we kick off this year's Super Replay Showdown. If you remember last year's inaugural tournament, you'll remember the rules. Several Game Informer editors (last year had eight entries, this year features ten) get a chance to choose the game that they'd most like to see as our next Super Replay. Then, they all compete in a tournament of random multiplayer gaming challenges to see which editor reigns supreme. Whoever wins the tournament gets to sit in on a full playthrough of the game they chose.
In this first week of the Showdown, you'll get a chance to see what games each of us will be fighting for. Also, I'm totally going to win the whole thing again.

secondSegmentGames: Buffy the Vampire Slayer: Chaos Bleeds

article.title: Replay – BloodRayne
article.author: Dan Ryckert
content: Vampires may be all over pop culture today, but they weren't quite as ubiquitous back in the early 2000s. They still reared their heads every once in a while, though, and one of those times was in BloodRayne for PS2. In this episode of Replay, we take a look at the first game in the series, which spawned films and a sequel.
Check it out below to see Andrew Reiner, Kim Wallace, Jason Oestreicher, and myself suck blood down in the swamps.

article.title: Replay – God Hand
article.author: Dan Ryckert
content: One of the downright goofiest games of the PlayStation 2 era was God Hand, a Capcom-published beat-em-up. While the game is rarely talked about, several of us at the office have some vague memories of insane attacks and a general wacky vibe. We decided to play it on this week's Replay to see how it holds up.
This episode features Andrew Reiner, Joe Juba, me, and everyone's favorite guest, Aram Jabbari (formerly Atlus PR, now with Sony).

article.title: Replay – Power Stone
article.author: Dan Ryckert
content: While far from a traditional entry in the genre, 1999's Power Stone was one of the most enjoyable fighters on the Dreamcast. With tons of environmental interaction, wacky weapons, and colorful characters, it managed to put forward a vibe that somewhat resembles that of Smash Bros. We decided to boot up the Dreamcast to check it out fourteen years after its initial release.
Watch below to see Jeff Cork, Bryan Vore, Jeff Marchiafava, and myself duke it out to see who reigns supreme in this great fighter (spoiler: it's totally me).

article.title: Replay – Pac-Man 2: The New Adventures
article.author: Jeff Cork
content: It's been a while since we saw our ol' buddy Pac-Man. What better way to welcome him back than to mercilessly pelt him with yellow spheres. Don't worry, he takes it pretty well. See for yourself in this new episode of Replay.

Dan takes the controls on this episode, and Reiner, Tim, and I watch with glee as he nearly devolves into a quivering mess. Spoiler: Dan has neither patience nor interest in reading tutorials. As you'll see, those are both traits that would have helped in this strange mix of an adventure and action game. Poor Pacs.
We've also got a roulette that proves to be a bit better than we'd anticipated, Just a bit.

episodeTitle: Replay: Haven: Call of the King

external_links.title: Replay: Haven: Call of the King
Replay: Haven: Call of the King

article.title: Replay – Haven: Call Of The King
article.author: Andrew Reiner
content: Before Traveller's Tales became the premiere developer of Lego-themed games, the company primarily worked with existing IP, such as Toy Story and Crash Bandicoot. In 2002, Traveller's Tales tried to develop its own universe in Haven: Call of the King, a game originally envisioned as the first chapter of an ongoing series. The game packed in an impressive amount of variety – with few if any load times between sections as diverse as platforming and aerial dogfighting. Join us for look at Haven's introductory moments, in what would become an odd footnote for Traveller's Tales.

description: Comedian James Adomian joins the crew on this episode.

article.title: Replay – Darkwing Duck (Guest: James Adomian)
article.author: Kyle Hilliard
content: This week we're taking a look at the classic Disney/Capcom collaboration, Darkwing Duck, and we invited comedian James Adomian to come join us.
We reached out to James because we're big fans of his appearances on podcasts like Comedy Bang Bang, but we were surprised to discover that who we really invited was a Darkwing Duck expert.

Unfortunately, James Adomian had to leave before we were able to jump into the Replay Roulette, but we were able to find a replacement guest at the last second. Hollywood star, former Minnesota governor, Navy Seal, and WWF superstar, Jesse "The Body" Ventura joined us to play some Nintendo games. He was definitely really here.

For more on James Adomian, you can follow him on Twitter, check out his Tumblr, and grab his new album Low Hangin Fruit from from the Earwolf podcast network. For more on Jesse Ventura, you can check out his Wikipedia page, I guess.

episodeTitle: Replay: The Legend of Zelda: Ocarina of Time

mainSegmentGamesAdv.title: The Legend of Zelda: Ocarina of Time

external_links.title: Replay: The Legend of Zelda: Ocarina of Time
Replay: The Legend of Zelda: Ocarina of Time

article.title: Replay – The Legend Of Zelda: Ocarina Of Time
article.author: Dan Ryckert
content: During the sea change from 2D to 3D gaming, Nintendo set incredibly high bars with their two flagship series. Mario set the standard for 3D platforming with the stellar Super Mario 64, and Link transitioned into 3D with equal grace. Many gamers (including myself) consider Ocarina of Time to be one of the greatest games of all time, and with good reason. Almost fifteen years since its 1998 release, we decided it was time to take a look back at the classic.
Watch below to see Andrew Reiner, Jeff Cork, Joe Juba, and me wax nostalgic over this gem and its place in history.

episodeTitle: Replay: The Sopranos: Road to Respect

external_links.title: Replay: The Sopranos: Road to Respect
Replay: The Sopranos: Road to Respect

article.title: Replay – The Sopranos: Road To Respect
article.author: Dan Ryckert
content: Licensed games are frequently of dubious quality, and the Playstation 2 certainly wasn't immune to this long-standing tradition. While many licensed games are based on children's shows or family-friendly movies, the PS2 played host to several titles based on more adult properties. We received awful-to-mediocre treatments of Reservoir Dogs, 24, Scarface, and this week's Replay...The Sopranos.
Watch below to see Andrew Reiner, Ben Reeves, departing intern Mike Mahardy, and me check out the HBO family's Road To Respect.

article.title: Replay – TimeSplitters 2
article.author: Tim Turi
content: This week we take a look at Free Radical Design's TimeSplitter's 2, which boasts many former Rare employees that worked on games like GoldenEye 007 on the N64 among its developers. We were amazed at just how many similarities there are between this goofy game and everyone's favorite N64 FPS when we popped in the PS2 version.

This week it's Andrew Reiner, Dan Ryckert, intern Mike Mahardy, and myself checking out TimeSplitters 2. This episode also marks the departure of Mike, who will be missed (until we forget about him). Stick around to see Reiner put his old-school gaming skills to the test in the second segment.

article.title: Replay – Warlock
article.author: Ben Reeves
content: Every thousand years, the sun and the moon align and the "evil one" sends his son to Earth to undo all of creation. Such is the story of the long forgotten Warlock franchise. We dust off this pulp classic and see if we can defy the evil one.
Watch Andrew Reiner, Kyle Hilliard, Ben Reeves, and Minnesota Vikings punter Chris Kluwe try to keep creation from becoming undid.

article.title: Replay – Shenmue
article.author: Dan Ryckert
content: One of the more polarizing games on the Sega Dreamcast was 2000's Shenmue. Directed by Yu Suzuki, this story-heavy action adventure title attracted many gamers but turned others off. With its slow pace, some grew tired of talking to random townspeople, participating in tedious side activities, and somewhat stiff combat. While that may be the case for some, the game has its share of fans at the Game Informer office. We decided to take a look back to see how it held up after a dozen years.
Check out the video player below to see Tim Turi, Andrew Reiner, Ben Reeves, and myself load up the Dreamcast and take control of Ryo Hazuki once again.

article.title: Replay – Pikmin
article.author: Dan Ryckert
content: Back in the fall of 2001, a great Gamecube title landed on store shelves only a couple of weeks after the console launched. Pikmin was the brainchild of legendary Nintendo designer Shigeru Miyamoto, and it's about to make its return on the Wii U with its third installment. Owners of Nintendo's new console should be excited, as it's been too long since we've had an armada of adorable aliens nipping at our heels.

Considering how long it's been since a new Pikmin was released, we decided to take a look back at the original. Join Andrew Reiner, intern Jordan LaPorte, myself, and a departing Jim Reilly as we guide Captain Olimar on his quest to repair his spaceship.

episodeTitle: Replay: Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas
secondSegmentGames: Grand Theft Auto: Liberty City Stories

description: Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas is the featured game in the one hundred fifty-fourth installment of Replay. It is one of the few games given a Perfect 10, and the second in the series to do so.

external_links.title: Replay: Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas
Replay: Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas

article.title: Replay – Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas
article.author: Dan Ryckert
content: The gaming world is eagerly awaiting Rockstar's return to San Andreas, so the Replay crew decided to take a trip back to 2004's massive GTA title. Playing as Carl "CJ" Johnson, this entry in the acclaimed series was one of the most ambitious games on the Playstation 2. Featuring three distinct cities and plenty of countryside in between, it encouraged plenty of exploration in its sprawling world. How does Rockstar's final PS2 installment fare all these years later?
Watch below to see Andrew Reiner, Matt Bertz, Kyle Hilliard, and myself take a trip back to the early 90s.

article.title: Replay – Resident Evil 0
article.author: Tim Turi
content: Capcom's legendary survival horror series initially manifested on the PlayStation, but its glory days burned hot on the GameCube. Shortly after the phenomenal Resident Evil remake, Capcom hit fans with a prequel starring S.T.A.R.S. Bravo Team medic, Rebecca Chambers.

Join Andrew Reiner, Benjamin Reeves, Kyle Hilliard, and myself as we dive back into this multi-protagonist entry in the celebrated series. How far will we make it on the Ecliptic Express? Will a certain over-sized anthropod get the best of us? Be sure to stick around for the return of a very special second segment.

article.title: Replay – PaRappa the Rapper
article.author: Kyle Hilliard
content: This week we're taking a look at a rappin' dog as he learns karate, gets his driver's license, and tries to sell flea market merchandise. We excel at every turn and rarely miss any of the rhythmic prompts. We're pretty much perfect at this game.

It's a small crew this week with temporary host Jeff Cork, Kyle Hillard, and extra special guest Matthew Kato. Two of us have an affection for this game, but one of us does not. See if you can figure out who in this week's episode of Replay. And don't forget to stick around for the Roulette!

episodeTitle: Replay: Alex Kidd in Miracle World

external_links.title: Replay: Alex Kidd in Miracle World
Replay: Alex Kidd in Miracle World

article.title: Replay – Alex Kidd In Miracle World
article.author: Jeff Cork
content: The Sega Master System never did reach a critical mass among gamers in the 8-bit days. Nintendo pretty much took the lead and ran with it. That doesn't mean that Tim and Jeff don't have a soft spot for the console. Bryan, however, remains skeptical. Alex Kidd isn't helping, either.

Watch as Tim does his best to battle Alex Kidd's floaty controls and frog-faced enemies. Either the game got harder over the years, or our Genesis adapter somehow messed around with the difficulty. That's the excuse we're going to be running with. Bryan wasn't ever exposed to the SMS, and it doesn't seem as though he's going to be converting anytime soon. Stick around for Replay Roulette, which features another classic-ish Master System game.

article.title: Replay – Cool Spot
article.author: Dan Ryckert
content: In our first exclusively junk food-related episode of Replay, we decided to take a look at a couple of 16-bit licensed platformers. For the main segment, we popped in Cool Spot, a 7up-themed game that several of us have fond memories of. Is it actually still good? Well, have any of you bought 7up in the last decade?
Watch below to see Jeff Cork, Ben Reeves, Joe Juba, and myself dive back into the fizzy waters of "the uncola."

article.title: Replay – Fatal Frame
article.author: Dan Ryckert
content: Halloween is quickly approaching, and we took a look around the vault for a suitably creepy title. We've covered survival horror classics like Resident Evil and Silent Hill before, but we wanted to dig a little deeper this time. Fatal Frame is a fondly-remembered PS2 series, and tasks the player with confronting baddies with a camera rather than a gun.
Watch below to see Tim Turi, Andrew Reiner, Jeff Cork, and myself relive this spooky title.

secondSegmentGames: Awesome Possum... Kicks Dr. Machino's Butt

description: Comedian and impressionist Frank Caliendo joins as a guest.

article.title: Replay – Chuck Rock (Guest: Frank Caliendo)
article.author: Dan Ryckert
content: Many editors here at Game Informer grew up loving 2D platformers, and returning to the genre is always fun for a look back. We weren't the only ones ready for some Genesis action, as comedian Frank Caliendo was a huge gamer as he grew up. He was in town for a stand-up gig, so I asked him if he'd be interested in swinging by. He accepted, and he's our special guest this week on Replay.
Watch below to see Frank, Tim Turi, Andrew Reiner, myself, and Frank's numerous impressions look back at Chuck Rock.

article.title: Replay – Donkey Kong 64
article.author: Dan Ryckert
content: Last week on Replay, the gang got into a heated argument that involved Banjo Kazooie, Super Mario 64, and 3D platforming in general. One of the titles that came up was Rare's Donkey Kong 64, which received decidedly mixed reactions upon its release. Thirteen years later, we decided to throw it into the Nintendo 64 to see how it holds up.
Watch below to see Tim Turi, Ben Hanson, Andrew Reiner, and myself continue our discussion about the era's platformers.

article.title: Replay – Banjo-Kazooie
article.author: Dan Ryckert
content: A few months ago, a bitter argument broke out between Tim Turi, Ben Hanson, and myself. Mr. Turi had the audacity of claiming that Banjo Kazooie was a better game than Super Mario 64, and we spent far too much time yelling at each other about it. I wanted to reignite this discussion on Replay, which leads us to this week's episode.
Watch below to see Andrew Reiner and the three of us discuss Banjo Kazooie's place in history.

article.title: Replay – Killer 7
article.author: Tim Turi
content: Aram Jabbari is possibly Replay's most popular guest of all time. Atlus' PR manager manages to find any excuse to come visit the Game Informer office. He masquerades these visits as appointments to show us new Atlus game, but we secretly believe he just can't get enough of Replay. He's back again to take a look at one of Capcom's "Capcom 5" GameCube games, Killer 7.

article.title: Replay – Virtual Bart
article.author: Dan Ryckert
content: Here at Game Informer, there's no shortage of big Simpsons fans. Obscure references from twenty years ago are still heard on a weekly basis here, and we doubt it'll be any different in another twenty. As gamers, we all would have liked to see some decent gaming experiences come out of the legendary franchise, but they've been few and far between. With awful titles like Simpsons Skateboarding, Simpsons Wrestling, and Bart vs. the Space Mutants, it hasn't been always been a pleasant ride for Homer and company. Despite this, we've had a few decent entries: The Simpsons Arcade Game, The Simpsons Hit & Run, the game based on the movie, and this week's episode of Replay.
Watch below to see Tim Turi, Andrew Reiner, everyone's favorite PR manager Aram Jabbari, and myself strap on our VR goggles and head back to Springfield.

secondSegmentGames: Battletoads & Double Dragon: The Ultimate Team

external_links.title: Replay: Double Dragon II: The Revenge
Replay: Double Dragon II: The Revenge

article.title: Replay – Double Dragon II: The Revenge
article.author: Kimberley Wallace
content: With the series' reboot Double Dragon Neon releasing this week on Xbox Live and PlayStation Network, we thought it would be fun to go back and play Double Dragon II: The Revenge. Is this beat-em-up still challenging us today as it did in our childhoods? Those Lee brothers sure had some girlfriend troubles.

Watch the video below where Bryan Vore explains all the tricks to winning, Ben Reeves provides the comedic entertainment, I tap into my childhood Double Dragon days of yore, and Andrew Reiner ponders the meaning of Double Dragon.

article.title: Replay – Stubbs The Zombie
article.author: Dan Ryckert
content: A few years before zombie games (and the zombie obsession in overall pop culture) became the rage, developer Wideload introduced gamers to an odd gaming protagonist: a chain-smoking, lovestruck member of the undead community. Armed only with flatulence and a hunger for brains, we stepped into his dirt-filled shoes for this week's Replay.
Watch below to see Andrew Reiner, Joe Juba, Ben Reeves, and myself return to this quirky Xbox original.

article.title: Replay – Zombies Ate My Neighbors
article.author: Kyle Hilliard
content: This week we're strapping on blue and red 3D glasses, saving some babies, and fighting monsters in Zombies Ate My Neighbors.

Regular Replay master of ceremonies Tim Turi hosts, along with Kyle Hilliard, the elusive Matt Bertz, and special guest Brent Weinbach. Brent makes his living as a comedian, hosts a podcast about video game music, and has a new album coming out this week. The rest of us are just lowly Game Informer editors. As always, stick around for the roulette. It's a weird one, but it's one you have probably heard of.

article.title: Replay – Headhunter
article.author: Dan Ryckert
content: In the early 2000s, Sega released a title that seemed (on the surface) to have it all. It had a cool dude with sunglasses and guns at a time when people were still optimistic about upcoming Matrix movies. Aesthetics aside, this game is pretty mediocre. With its frustrating vehicular segments and ho-hum action, it's surprising that it eventually spawned a sequel.
Watch below to see Joe Juba, Andrew Reiner, and intern Jack Frontier attempt to wring any fun out of Headhunter.

description: Game creator Warren Spector guest stars on this episode.

article.title: Replay – Deus Ex With Special Guest Warren Spector
article.author: Kyle Hilliard
content: This week we're taking a look at the 2000 PC classic Deus Ex with the mastermind himself, Warren Spector.

Ben Hanson, Adam Biessener, myself, one of Epic Mickey 2's producers Raul Ramirez, and Warren Spector all sat down only to stand right back up and take a stroll down memory lane, making sure to stick to the shadows wherever possible. Spector talks about how he was moments away from signing a contract with Electronic Arts to create a Command & Conquer RPG, when John Romero called him up and made him an offer he couldn't refuse. We also take a look at at one of Warren's favorite games that influences his work even today with the development of Epic Mickey in our Replay Roulette.

article.title: Replay – Pocky & Rocky
article.author: Andrew Reiner
content: Game Informer's month-long celebration of co-op gaming once again extends to Replay, our silly show that revisits gaming's past. In this episode, Atlus' Aram Jabbari joins Joe Juba, Tim Turi, and I for a fun look back at Natsume's co-op action game Pocky & Rocky. Playing this title ends up being a learning experience for our team. We can now identify the difference between a raccoon and a Japanese raccoon dog on sight. Sit back and enjoy the episode, folks, and be sure to stick around for a second segment that explores a long lost Sega Genesis relic.

article.title: Replay – Contra
article.author: Tim Turi
content: The upcoming issue of Game Informer includes a comprehensive look back at the best co-op games of all time. Now is the perfect time to dive into the one of the most memorable 8-bit cooperative games ever: Contra.

Join Bryan Vore, Andrew Reiner, Kyle Hilliard, and myself as we tackle one the NES's most beloved titles. Can you guess how far Bryan and I get into the long fight against non-descript bad guys? Can we remember the legendary Konami code? Find out, then stick around for our thrilling second segment.

article.title: Replay – Viewtiful Joe
article.author: Ben Reeves
content: Before game director Hideki Kamiya brought us Ōkami and Bayonetta, he designed a stylish 2D brawler for the GameCube called Viewtiful Joe. In a plot stolen from an Arnold Schwarzenegger film, Joe jumps into a movie in order to save his girlfriend.
Join Tim Turi, Andrew Reiner, Jim Reilly, and myself as we warp time in Viewtiful Joe and then warp our minds during the Replay Roulette.

article.title: Replay – Darkwatch
article.author: Tim Turi
content: Before Highmoon Studios was tackling licenses like The Transformers and Deadpool, it created a new IP about a vampiric cowboy with a thirst for blood and murder. We saddled up this 2005 original Xbox title to see how she looks after all these years, and we were surprised by what we found.

Join Joe Juba, Andrew Reiner, Kyle Hilliard, and myself as we blast our way through hordes of nightmarish creatures and fail spectacularly at riding a horse. Stick around for our second segment, which is an exciting new addition to Replay.

article.title: Replay – Die Hard Vendetta
article.author: Dan Ryckert
content: Several Game Informer editors are big fans of John McClane, but we're still disappointed that we haven't seen a genuinely great Die Hard game. Given the right developer, McClane's trip to Nakatomi Plaza could make for a tense and action-packed gaming experience. Instead, we have Die Hard Vendetta. Developed by Bits Studios (who also made games based on Constantine, Last Action Hero, and Itchy & Scratchy), it's a 2002 Gamecube title that did little to please fans of the film franchise.
Watch below to see Tim Turi, Andrew Reiner, Intern Jack Frontier, and myself play this disappointing (and Bruce Willis-less) shooter.

article.title: Replay – Blood Wake
article.author: Andrew Reiner
content: Epic Games' Rod Fergusson and Wes Phillips join the Replay crew for an informative and competitive look back at Microsoft's Blood Wake. Rod worked on this game before joining Epic. He shares plenty of interesting stories about its development and reception. He even throws down against the Replay crew in a four-player split-screen battle. Stick around for our second segment for a look at another game that Rod developed and Wes kicked ass in. If you want a deeper look at Rod's game development history, Game Informer's August issue holds a "My First Game" entry for him and the game Microsoft Train Simulator.

article.title: Replay – Psi-Ops
article.author: Dan Ryckert
content: Gamers have always loved the idea of using the Force to destroy enemies, but developers have rarely nailed the feeling we've hoped for. Star Wars games have been notoriously hit and miss, but a 2004 Midway title did a damn good job of presenting the telekinetic powers we've always wanted. While it's obviously not an official Star Wars game, it features protagonist Nick Scryer tossing scientists and soldiers around with the power of a Sith lord. We decided to revisit this hidden gem for this week's Replay.
Be sure to stick around for the second segment, in which we resurrect a popular new feature to chaotic results.

article.title: Replay – Max Payne GBA
article.author: Tim Turi
content: Before you yell "Hey, you guys already did a Replay of Max Payne!" at your computer screen, I implore you to take a look at the screen above. That is definitely not the original Max Payne. No, it's actually the Game Boy Advance version of the game. But don't write off this less-powerful version of the game yet; check out our surprising Replay first.

Join Matt Helgeson, Andrew Reiner, Kyle Hilliard, and myself as we plug in another chapter of gaming's biggest sad sack. The isometric view may be a bit clunky at times, but you'll be shocked by how convincing the Bullet Time effect looks.

description: The featured Gamecube version was given a Perfect 10 in the March 2005 issue, the PlayStation 2 would get another 10 in the November 2005 issue.

article.title: Replay – Resident Evil 4
article.author: Dan Ryckert
content: Resident Evil is one of the most well-known series in gaming history, and gamers are eagerly anticipating the holiday release of the sixth core entry in the franchise. While it may feel recent, Resident Evil 4 fits within the Replay boundaries by releasing before the current generation of consoles. When it released in 2005, it turned Resident Evil conventions on their head with a new perspective and more of a focus on action. We decided to give it a try seven years later to see how it holds up.
Watch below to see our look back, featuring Tim Turi, Andrew Reiner, myself, and a special appearance by my father Paul Ryckert.

episodeTitle: Replay: Sword of the Berserk: Guts' Rage

mainSegmentGamesAdv.title: Sword of the Berserk: Guts' Rage

external_links.title: Replay: Sword of the Berserk: Guts' Rage
Replay: Sword of the Berserk: Guts' Rage

article.title: Replay – Sword Of The Berserk
article.author: Dan Ryckert
content: During the Playstation 2 era, gamers saw the rise of stylish and ultra-violent action games in the vein of Devil May Cry and God of War. While Sword of the Berserk: Guts' Rage can't touch the quality of those series, Eidos gave the genre a shot early in the days of the Dreamcast. We grabbed it from the vault to see if it holds up today.
Watch below to see Tim Turi, Andrew Reiner, Jeff Cork, and myself dust off the Dreamcast for a look at this manga-inspired bloodbath.

article.title: Replay – Batman Forever
article.author: Dan Ryckert
content: Back in 1995, Warner Bros. launched an all-out marketing assault surrounding the release of Batman Forever. Music videos by Seal and U2 that featured clips from the movie were all over MTV, a dedicated comic was made, and McDonald's offered several limited-edition glass mugs featuring characters from the film. Of course, video games were part of the marketing package as well. Games based on the movie came to 16-bit consoles and the arcade, the latter of which found its way to Playstation in late 1996. We decided to give it a try as this week's episode of Replay, and it's certainly something...special?
Watch below to see Andrew Reiner, Tim Turi, Jeff Cork and myself relive the glory of the Schumacher era of Batman.

article.title: Replay – Gunstar Heroes
article.author: Tim Turi
content: Besides the so-so Contra: Hard Corps, Sega fans couldn't play any entry from Konami's awesome shooter series on the Genesis. Fortunately, the spectacular Treasure title, Gunstar Heroes, hit the Genesis in full force. The co-op run and gun shooter allowed two players to mix and match power-ups in the age-old quest to kill everything onscreen.

This week we're joined by Brent Weinbach, comedian, host of The Legacy Music Hour, and friend of Replay. Brent previously joined us for a look back at Magical Quest Starring Mickey Mouse, and he's back to play Gunstar Heroes with Ben Reeves, Kyle Hilliard, and myself.

secondSegmentGames: Shin Nippon Pro Wrestling: Toukon Retsuden 3

description: Fighting Force is the title game of the one hundred twenty sixth episode of Replay .
Kyle hosts and is joined by Tim, Dan, and Reiner. Tim and Dan take the sticks as they play through the 1997 beat 'em up game.

article.title: Replay – Fighting Force
article.author: Dan Ryckert
content: Brawlers were in their prime back in the 16-bit era, but the genre seemed to stall a bit once the industry shifted to 3D gaming. Despite the lull, Eidos and Core attempted to emulate the beat-em-up heyday with the 3D Fighting Force. All of the genre standbys (eating food off the ground, beating up environmental objects, swarms of similarly-named baddies) were present, including co-op play.
Watch below to see Tim and I bash faces in while playing as Hawk and Smasher.

secondSegmentGames: Rocko's Modern Life: Spunky's Dangerous Day

article.title: Replay – Home Improvement
article.author: Dan Ryckert
content: Once every couple of months, I think to myself "why haven't we done a Replay of Home Improvement for Super Nintendo?". Whenever I check the Vault after that thought, however, I remember that it's one of our few missing games. Our video editor Jason pointed this out on a recent episode, and a fateful package arrived soon after here in Minneapolis. Thanks to the generosity of Replay fan Rohn Huntone, we can finally play this amazing game.
Watch below to witness the fateful journey of Tim Turi, Andrew Reiner, Ben Reeves, and myself as we take a nail gun to velociraptors in an effort to find our lost Binford tools.

article.title: Replay – Treasures of the Deep
article.author: Ben Reeves
content: Get ready to get wet. Treasures of the Deep is a 1997 release that allowed player to capture dolphins in nets and kill every marine animal known to man. Also, you can kill man. Why didn’t PETA ever sink their teeth into this game? Watch out for that shark!
Join Andrew Reiner, Jeff Cork, Ben Reeves, and Tim Turi as we explore the bottom of the seas, and discuss why James Bond never jumps. Then we play another game, but that’s not really important.

article.title: Replay – Mischief Makers
article.author: Tim Turi
content: This week we take a look at an old Nintendo 64 title you may not have taken the time to check out during the system's glory days. This gem by Treasure has players assume the role of a robotic maid-thing that hurts enemies by shaking the crap out of them. It's inventive, cute, and an overall good time. Stick around for a brand new segment during the second half of Replay.

Andrew Reiner, Joe Juba, Kyle Hilliard, and myself will be your guides for this week's Replay. Be sure to check out the twisted, intense fun of our very backwards new Replay Roulette segment, You're Doing it Wrong.

episodeTitle: Replay: Alone in the Dark: One-Eyed Jack's Revenge

mainSegmentGamesAdv.title: Alone in the Dark: One-Eyed Jack's Revenge

external_links.title: Replay: Alone in the Dark: One-Eyed Jack's Revenge
Replay: Alone in the Dark: One-Eyed Jack's Revenge

article.title: Replay – Alone in the Dark: One-Eyed Jack's Revenge
article.author: Ben Reeves
content: Alone in the Dark: One-Eyed Jack's Revenge is the PSone adaptation of the sequel to a genuine cult PC classic. But the only thing scary about this early survival horror title is its clunky controls and loading screens that can pop out of any corner.

Join Andrew Reiner, Tim Turi, Dan Ryckert, and Ben Reeves as they struggle to look past the horrifying graphics and stilted controls of this 1996 horror title. Stick around for our Roulette where we play another game with terrible controls and graphics. Yeah, that’s right, they made two bad games that generation.

description: Friday The 13th is the featured game on the one hundred twentyfirst episode of Replay. This episode was hosted by Andrew Reiner , who is joined by Joe Juba , Tim Turi and Jason Oestreicher.
This episode was uploaded on the actual Friday the 13th (one day earlier than usual) and also introduced the Horror Fest second segment.

article.title: Replay – Friday The 13th
article.author: Andrew Reiner
content: As a special treat to Friday the 13th observers, we've decided to air this week's episode of Replay a day early. Join Joe Juba, Tim Turi, Jason Oestreicher, and I as we travel back to the long forgotten NES slasher game, Friday the 13th. Tim makes sure that he shows us the game's "good" ending. Rather than doing a standard Roulette this week, we decided to keep our love of horror alive in two bonus segments.

Super Replay Update: If you're wondering where our Half-Life Super Replay is, we ran into a slight delay due to a magazine deadline. We'll begin recording episodes next Thursday, and will hopefully air them the following week. Keep in mind that these plans are tentative. We're doing everything we can to get them out as quickly as we can. Thanks for your patience!

episodeTitle: Replay: Might and Magic II: Isles of Terra

mainSegmentGamesAdv.title: Might and Magic III: Isles of Terra

description: Might and Magic III: Isles of Terra is the title game of the one hundred twentieth episode of Replay. The Japanese-only Tobal 2 is featured in this episode's second segment, RePorted.
Jason hosts and is joined by Adam, Jeff Cork, and Tim. Adam plays Might and Magic III and all four end up playing Tobal 2.
notes: Bonus episode.

external_links.title: Replay: Might and Magic III: Isles of Terra
Replay: Might and Magic III: Isles of Terra
Might and Magic III: Isles of Terra
Might and Magic III: Isles of Terra

article.title: Replay – Might And Magic III: Isles Of Terra
article.author: Tim Turi
content: Nobody really knew what was in store for them when Adam dragged us all down into the Replay recording room. The glittery nostalgic gleam in his eyes cued us in that we were going to play some game he adored as a kid, but none of us had ever played Might and Magic III. After trusting Adam as our guide and plunging into the moose rat-infested pits of Fountain Head, we emerge with a new, err... appreciation of the classic PC RPG.

Join Jeff Cork, Adam Biessener, your host Jason Oestreicher, and myself as we return to the mystical land of Terra in 1991's Might and Magic III. Stick around for the second segment in which we play a game that confuses the hell out of us. Surprise!

description: Kid Icarus is the title game of the one hundred nineteenth episode of Replay. The Replay Roulette is Jurassic Park for NES.
This episode features Reiner as host, along with Jeff Cork, Bryan, and Dan. All four take turns playing.

article.title: Replay – Kid Icarus
article.author: Dan Ryckert
content: Nintendo has always been fond of keeping their franchises alive, but it took numerous console generations for Pit to return in Kid Icarus: Uprising. His NES original is one of the most notoriously difficult games of all time, so we decided to dust off our cartridge and re-examine it for this week's episode of Replay.
Watch below to see Andrew Reiner, Jeff Cork, Bryan Vore, and myself try as hard as we can to beat the first stage.

episodeTitle: Replay: Beethoven: The Ultimate Canine Caper

description: Beethoven: The Ultimate Canine Caper is the title game of the one hundred eighteenth episode of Replay. Segment 2 is the finale round of Super Replay Showdown.
This episode features Reiner as host, Dan and Ben Reeves, and Tim playing Beethoven.
notes: The title on the game's box reads Beethoven: The Ultimate Canine Caper, but the title screen displays Beethoven's 2nd.
quotes: Beethoven

Tim: "Local dog barks child to death while skateboarding. Experts are still on the case reporting, 'We've never seen a bark-related death.' This is one case where the dog's bark is certainly worse than its bite."
Tim: "Get away from my son!"

external_links.title: Replay: Beethoven: The Ultimate Canine Caper
Replay: Beethoven: The Ultimate Canine Caper

article.title: Replay – Beethoven
article.author: Tim Turi
content: This week's game selection was a head-scratcher right out of the gate. The box calls the game Beethoven: The Ultimate Canine Caper, while the title screen says Beethoven's 2nd. This isn't just a one-off flub, either -- the rest of the game is also a wet, sloppy mess, much like Beethoven himself.

Join Andrew Reiner, Dan Ryckert, Ben Reeves, and myself as we struggle through the often confusing, sometimes surprising, but consistently frustrating adventures of a lovable Saint Bernard. Also, stick around for the second segment in which we crown the winner of the Super Replay Showdown. It's down to Ben Reeves (representing Conker's Bad Fur Day), and Dan Ryckert (Half-Life). Who. Will. Go. All. The. Way!?
The first episode of the winning Super Replay will air next week.

episodeTitle: Replay: The Beast Within: A Gabriel Knight Mystery

mainSegmentGamesAdv.title: The Beast Within: A Gabriel Knight Mystery

description: The Beast Within: A Gabriel Knight Mystery is the title game of the one hundred seventeenth episode of Replay. The Replay Roulette is Crime Life: Gang Wars on Xbox.
Reiner hosts, Joe plays using a Phantom Lapboard and Phil and Jeff watch. Joe also plays the Roulette.
notes: This bonus episode was chosen by Phil to compliment his Classic GI article on the Gabriel Knight series in the May 2012 issue of the magazine.
This episode's second segment erroneously uses the Replay intro animation instead of the Roulette intro.
quotes: The Beast Within: A Gabriel Knight Mystery
Joe: "Also, the person-to-ridiculous-hat ratio in this crowd is very high."

external_links.title: Replay: The Beast Within: A Gabriel Knight Mystery
Replay: The Beast Within: A Gabriel Knight Mystery
The Beast Within: A Gabriel Knight Mystery
The Beast Within: A Gabriel Knight Mystery

article.title: Replay – Gabriel Knight: The Beast Within
article.author: Phil Kollar
content: Since this is my last week here at Game Informer, the higher-ups made the mistake of letting me choose what game to check out in a special bonus edition of Replay. I chose The Beast Within: A Gabriel Knight Mystery, one of my favorite adventure games of all time and the reason I have a soft spot for full-motion video.

On this episode, I'm joined by Jeff Cork, Andrew Reiner, and Joe Juba as we discover the latest predicament that supernatural investigator Gabriel Knight finds himself in. Be prepared for ridiculous hats, "verevolves," and some early info from an article on the Gabriel Knight series that will be running in the May issue of Game Informer.

description: Harley's Humongous Adventure is the featured game of the one hundred sixteenth episode of Replay. Segment 2 is round 2 of Super Replay Showdown.
Reiner hosts and Ben and Dan play Harley while Jeff watches.
quotes: Harley's Humongous Adventure
Ben: "Oh, you can shoot up? Oh my gosh, that's amazing! That changes the game!"
Dan: "I've got an onion ring around me. I'm invincible."

article.title: Replay – Harley's Humongous Adventure
article.author: Dan Ryckert
content: Visual Concepts is most widely known for their work on the numerous 2K Sports games. That wasn't always their bread and butter, however, as they put out this bite-sized platformer for the Super Nintendo in 1993. Join Reiner, Jeff Cork, Ben Reeves, and myself as we put it to the test.
Also, be sure to stick around after Harley to see the exciting Super Replay Showdown installment that addresses Phil's departure and determines the finals of the competition!

description: Hercules: The Legendary Journeys is the title game of the one hundred fifteenth episode of Replay. Segment 2 is Super Replay Showdown.
Reiner hosts, Dan plays Hercules, and Tim and Joe watch.
quotes: Hercules
Dan: "Oh, Danny Trejo's the centaur! I just realized that."
Dan: "Don't drop it on your own head! It's gonna hurt your noggin, Hercules!"
Tim: "The traditional way to end a Replay is getting beaten to death."

article.title: Replay – Hercules
article.author: Dan Ryckert
content: We've played some Titus games before on Replay, and the results haven't been pretty. We're not dumb enough to think things would be any different with a licensed Nintendo 64 game, but we decided to try out Hercules anyway.

Join myself, Andrew Reiner, Tim Turi, and Joe Juba as we lift rocks and discover the sexy side of Kevin Sorbo. Also, make sure to stick around for the second segment, in which Reiner takes on Phil and Joe Juba takes on yours truly to determine the final four of the Super Replay Showdown!

episodeTitle: Replay: Spy Hunter: Nowhere to Run

description: Spy Hunter: Nowhere to Run is the title game of the one hundred fourteenth episode of Replay. Segment 2 is Super Replay Showdown.
Andrew Reiner hosts and Ben Reeves plays Spy Hunter. They are joined by Bryan Vore and Phil Kollar.
quotes: Spy Hunter
Bryan: "He's got permanent, like, concentration eyebrows."
Ben: "He just pulled a gun out of his nowhere."
Phil: "Did you just try doing a wrestling move on that missile?"

external_links.title: Replay: Spy Hunter: Nowhere to Run
Replay: Spy Hunter: Nowhere to Run

article.title: Replay – Spy Hunter: Nowhere To Run
article.author: Phil Kollar
content: For most people, if I say "Spy Hunter," you'll probably think of the arcade action-racing classic or one of its early console ports. For us here at Replay, that name brings a much darker image to mind, and it's one that includes pro wrestler The Rock.

Spy Hunter: Nowhere to Run is one of the worst late-era Midway games, adapting a beloved franchise into a a bland action game. It was originally supposed to be backed up by a movie (starring the Rock, of course), but that film seems to be forever trapped in development hell.

On this week's Replay I'm joined by Andrew Reiner, Ben Reeves, and Bryan Vore as we discover what it truly feels like to be trapped in the body of the Rock and the joys of body-slamming dudes onto lasers.
Stay tuned after the regular Replay for week two of Super Replay Showdown. This week Tim Turi faces off against Kyle Hilliard, and Ben Reeves stares down the gaping maw of despair that is Jeff Cork.

description: Fox Hunt is the featured game of the one hundred thirteenth episode of Replay.

article.title: Replay – Fox Hunt
article.author: Phil Kollar
content: I harbor a dark secret: Despite their goofiness and lack of actual, engaging gameplay, I have a serious soft spot for full-motion video (or FMV) games. So imagine my surprise when Capcom community manager and friend of Replay Brett Elston informed me of an FMV game for the PS1 that I had never heard of.

On this week's Replay, I force Andrew Reiner, Dan Ryckert, and Tim Turi to join me for a look at Capcom's long-lost Fox Hunt. This "interactive comedy spy thriller" has some of the strangest gameplay we've ever encountered in the Replay room and is full of surprises...and dumb faces.

Be sure to stick around after the regular Replay for a very special second segment. The GI editors have been teasing our work on "Project Mako" for a few weeks now, and it begins here. Look at the text under the video for further information.

episodeTitle: Replay: The Magical Quest Starring Mickey Mouse

mainSegmentGamesAdv.title: The Magical Quest Starring Mickey Mouse

description: The Magical Quest Starring Mickey Mouse is the 112th episode of Replay. It was posted to the Game Informer website on February 25, 2012.

This episode is hosted by Tim Turi and features Andrew Reiner, Kyle Hilliard, Ben Hanson, and special guest Brent Weinbach, comedian and host of the Legacy Music Hour podcast, who also chose the game for this episode. During the episode, they discuss music and other Mickey Mouse games, as well as Tim and Brent sharing a moment in the Vault. Ben Hanson does an impressive Mickey Mouse impersonation. Brent constantly tells the Replay team that he wishes he had more time to show them level 3 or 5.

The episode's second segment is Reported, in which the crew plays Rhythm Heaven, known as Rhythm Tengoku in Japan, for the GBA. According to Ben Hanson, Rhythm Heaven is not actually in the Game Informer vault, the copy of Rhythm Heaven that the crew plays is his personal copy which he imported.
notes: According to Brent, a major reason why he chose Magical Quest for this episode is because he is a huge fan of this game's soundtrack. Also, it's same composer for Breath of Fire.
Hanson learned "left" and "right" in Japanese from a particular mini-game in Rhythm Heaven.
quotes: (17:07) Hanson: That beaver's ready for blood!
(17:22) Tim: (sees a star-shaped object in the water) Is that a...
(17:24) Tim: (jumps on the star and takes damage) No! You don't just--
(17:25) Kyle: That was a pickup.
(17:29) Tim: They're playing with gaming convention. This is like Eternal Darkness.
(22:15) Brent: I really like this part. (listens) I realy like this part too. (listens) The next part is really good too.
(27:18) Kyle: His power is taking his pants off.

Replay: Magical Quest Starring Mickey Mouse
The Magical Quest Starring Mickey Mouse
The Magical Quest Starring Mickey Mouse

article.title: Replay – Magical Quest Starring Mickey Mouse
article.author: Tim Turi
content: This week we dust off an old SNES cartridge to reveal the vivid, whimsical Disney platformer beneath. Comedian and video game music aficionado Brent Weinbach joins us as a special guest as we face off against the grotesque mutant offspring of Pete, jog on a gigantic tomato, and generally get our asses handed to us.

In addition to Brent, the cast this week features Andrew Reiner, Kyle Hilliard, Ben Hanson, and myself as host. Thanks to Brent for taking a break from making people laugh really hard and hosting the terrific Legacy Music Hour podcast. Check out the Legacy Music Hour (available on iTunes) if you want to fill your ears with tasty 8- and 16-bit music as well as delectable discussion about said tracks.

description: 50 Cent: Bulletproof is the 111th episode of Replay. It was posted to the Game Informer website on February 18th, 2012.
This episode is hosted by Phil Kollar and features Tim Turi (on controls), Kyle Hilliard, and special guest Haydn Dalton, lead designer of Darksiders II at Vigil Games.

The episode's second segment is the debut of Developer Pick, in which the developer who is the guest of the episode chooses a game to play. Haydn Dalton chooses Venom/Spider-Man: Separation Anxiety, which he and Tim play co-op.
notes: 50 Cent: Bulletproof was chosen for this replay because Haydn Dalton worked on the game before he worked on Darksiders and Darksiders II. He also worked on Venom/Spider-Man: Separation Anxiety, which is why he chose the game for the Developer Pick segment.
quotes: Venom/Spider-Man: Separation Anxiety:
Tim: "Yes! I just threw a woman at that man."

article.title: Replay – 50 Cent: Bulletproof
article.author: Phil Kollar
content: Sometimes on Replay we reminisce about old games that we love, and other times we function as therapy. On this week's episode, Tim Turi, Kyle Hilliard, and I are joined by special guest Haydn Dalton, the lead designer of Darksiders II. Haydn was also involved in developing a notoriously flawed but distressingly successful game called 50 Cent: Bulletproof.

We sit Haydn down for his first serious time with Bulletproof since he shipped the game. In addition to some goofing around, Haydn gives us some great insight into how troubled development can drag down talented game makers and some of the problems this specific project faced. After that, Haydn sticks around to show us another slightly less terrible project that he has his fingerprints on.

Special thanks go out to Haydn for being such a good sport in taking a look at what was surely a difficult project for him and putting up with our dumb jokes. Show him some love by checking out the first Darksiders if you haven't yet. It's awesome! You can check out more of Haydn's commentary and Darksiders in the developer commentary video that we recorded last summer.

description: In this episode, the team consists of Andrew Reiner, Ben Reeves, and Tim Turi. They acknowledge their reduced number, due to Dan's mysterious disappearance coinciding with his father's appearance.

The episode starts with each of the team relating their experience with the game. Tim Turi has none, Andrew Reiner can faintly remember enjoying it, and Ben Reeves also has negligible experience. Reiner recalls especially enjoying the humor, and Tim appreciates the the Ghosts 'n' Ghoulies look of the game. Tim ponders if Sir Dan is a joke, as it reminds him of Iron Maiden's mascot.Tim gets annoyed with the camera, and Reiner digs up the other projects of the team behind MediEvil which are mostly ports of popular console game to handehelds(LBP for PSP, Killzone for Vita, etc.). As they backtrack for a Chalice, Reiner recalls a wrestling/gambling competition where Dan kept track of stats in crayon. Sir Dan gains access to the Hall of Heroes, and acquires a crossbow from an old subordinate. He contiunes to Cemetary Hill, where Princess Leia tries to kill him with boulders. Tim muses on the inconsistency of the zombie speed, and Reeves ptiches the idea for Jaoquin Dead, a spin-off of Walking Dead, starring Joaquin Pheonix. Sir Dan defeats the onslaught of boulders, and the gargoyles commit suicide in shame. Reeves says that is the same thing all editors must do if an article is not in on time, and is probably what happened to Dan. Tim says he was biting down on a Waluigi sandwich and accidentally activated his fake tooth with a cyanide pill and died. They explore a labrynth and encounter a harrowing stained-glass golem. After a tense fight, Tim defeats the golem.

They begin the Roulette, which is Juggernaut, a game that begins with evil Blood Moons, evil clown clocks, and evil dolls. A clingy boyfriend wants to talk to his girlfriend shapes the premise. Tim mocks the slow text of the Myst-style game, as an exorcist tells the clingy boyfriend that his girlfriend has had her soul stolen by an evil force. He must exorcise from within what is left of her soul. He enters a blood bag lit world, but unfortunately has no time to blood fish. He talks to Zorro, then steals his watch and searches for paintings. After a few more puzzles to no avail, the team ends the Replay.
quotes: Reeves: "This doesn't seem right at all!" Tim: "Turn to the right, and leave!"
Tim: "It's-the-doll-Sarah-loves."

article.title: Replay – MediEvil
article.author: Tim Turi
content: The PlayStation served as a training ground for many developers looking to tap the new market for 3D games. One such game is MediEvil, a goofy, Halloween-coated action game that put players in the greaves of the deceased knight Sir Dan. Does the 1998 gameplay hold up? Or is it showing signs of decomposition?

Join your host Andrew Reiner, Ben Reeves, and myself as we dust off this PlayStation relic and have another go. We confront hordes of over-caffeinated zombies, conquer piles of broken glass, and engage in a harrowing battle with a stained glass golem.

episodeTitle: Replay: Alex Kidd in the Enchanted Castle

mainSegmentGamesAdv.title: Alex Kidd in the Enchanted Castle

description: Alex Kidd in the Enchanted Castle is the 109th episode of Replay. It was posted to the Game Informer website on February 7th, 2012. This episode's second segment is a Replay Roulette of the game Kid Chameleon.
This episode is hosted by Andrew Reiner and features Bryan Vore, Dan Ryckert, and Phil Kollar, with Jason Oestreicher on video and technical duties (with occasional commentary).
editor_antics: At first, the staff (especially Dan Ryckert) are doubtful of the game because of the one-hit kills and Janken (rock-paper-scissors) minigame. However, once Bryan takes the controls and buys a motorcycle, Dan declares himself sold and both Reiner and Phil are impressed. However, their attitude once again sours as one-hit kills abound. Then Dan makes a Terminator reference (of course). They discuss the possibility of fans favoring Alex Kidd over Mario, which Dan finds absurd (of course). Reiner complains that Alex is always smiling, and Dan defends him by saying that he "just loves punching animals". Reiner begins to demand that Dan provide a death sound for Alex, which Dan refuses to do. Reiner threatens to fire him (of course).
alex_kidd.27s_antics: Alex explores a town, prairie, underwater level and a desert. Despite amusing animations, a carefree attitude, oddly proportioned fists, and a motorcycle Alex finds progress difficult and eventually succumbs from the combined efforts of a bounce block and a mummy.
replay_roulette: The Roulette episode is Kid Chameleon, which opens with Reiner apologizing for the absence of Replay 2037 and Dan rejoicing it. They immediately make fun of Kid Chameleon's appearance, and Bryan Vore shares a story of how a kid he went to high school with was the inspiration for Kid Chameleon(the kid's father was the box artist). Bryan murders mecha-gorillas with a samurai sword, and Reiner relates how he beat Chikan, a notoriously bad game. They reach the second level, where Bryan turns into a Rhino and fights Gish. They complete the level and play through a little of the next before ending the Roulette.

external_links.title: Replay: Alex Kidd in the Enchanted Castle
Replay: Alex Kidd in the Enchanted Castle
Alex Kidd in the Enchanted Castle

article.title: Replay – Alex Kidd In The Enchanted Castle
article.author: Dan Ryckert
content: During the console wars of the early 90s, Nintendo was represented by Mario and Sega had Sonic in their corner. While these faces were the most famous, Sega had a popular platformer of their own before Sonic took off. In this week's Replay, we take a look back at a series that has essentially been abandoned as the industry moved forward.
Watch below to see Andrew Reiner, Bryan Vore, Phil Kollar, and myself take a look back at Alex Kidd In The Enchanted Castle.

description: Bubsy 3D is the title game of the one hundred eighth episode of Replay. This episode's second segment is the debut of Reported, in which the editors play the European PlayStation game Hugo.
Andrew Reiner hosts this episode, which also features Ben Reeves, Tim Turi, and Dan Ryckert. Tim plays Bubsy and Ben plays Hugo.
notes: The whole Replay crew was fed up with Bubsy 3D after about 15 minutes and moved on.A new second segment in which the editors play a game never released in North America, Reported, was introduced in this episode.
quotes: Bubsy 3D:
Dan: "Is that supposed to be a film reel or is that a Communion wafer?"
Dan: "Bubsy's quest for the body of Christ!"
Hugo:
Reiner: "Europe is so weird."
Tim: "No, but seriously, why did they move so close next to the, uh, the skull mountain?"
Ben: "Good gravy, that's not good."
Tim: "I love sacks! Oh boy!"
Tim: "A good burlap sack is completely empty!"

article.title: Replay – Bubsy 3D
article.author: Dan Ryckert
content: When the gaming world turned its eye to 3D in the 32/64-bit era, some franchises made the leap gracefully. Mario and Link knocked the ball out of the park with their three-dimensional debuts, Super Mario 64 and Ocarina of Time. Bubsy did not make that same leap. While he was certainly no Mario or Link to begin with, this wretched platformer ensured that the snarky bobcat would become a gaming footnote at best.

Bubsy 3D was a notoriously awful title when it released in 1996, and we expected the worst when we decided to revisit it 16 years later. You can watch Tim Turi, Andrew Reiner, Ben Reeves, and myself struggle with the title below, and be sure to stay tuned for the second segment.

description: GoldenEye 007 is the title game of the one hundred seventh episode of Replay and the debut episode of the second season. The second segment is Replay 2037, a segment where the crew takes a "look back" at Uncharted 2: Among Thieves from the perspective of gamers in the year 2037.
This episode is hosted by Andrew Reiner and features Ben Reeves, Tim Turi, and Dan Ryckert. Tim plays GoldenEye's single-player and all four play multiplayer.
notes: This episode marks the beginning of Replay's second season, and the debut of a new segment, Replay 2037.
quotes: Goldeneye:
Tim: "I wanna kill all these guys down here real quick."
Uncharted 2: Drake's Deception
Reeverbot: "I dated a Playstation 6 once...she kept playing games with my heart."

article.title: Replay – GoldenEye 007
article.author: Andrew Reiner
content: Welcome to Replay’s second season! While it may seem arbitrary to end a season after two years and over 100 episodes, we’ve never been sticklers for making sense or following rules.

I came up with the idea of a second season over a year ago, but wanted to bat around ideas with the Replay crew regarding new elements to make sure Season 2 wasn’t just a logo change. While this is still the same Replay you know and love, we’re going to have more fun with the second segment. We enjoyed taking shorter looks at our Roulette games, but we wanted more creative freedom for the second segment. Dan, Tim and I have thrown around dozens of new ideas – ranging from the informative to the insane – and we like the idea of our viewers not knowing what the second segment will be. We’ll still do Roulette on occasion, but as you’ll see in the weeks ahead, you’ll frequently be met with surprises.

After viewing our lengthy look at GoldenEye 007, a highly requested title from our viewers and Replay cast, you’ll get the first taste of the type of things we can do with this second segment. It’s one of our wackier ideas, and there’s a chance it won’t return, but we’d like to create an air of unpredictability with each episode as we move forward.

The Replay crew extends big thanks to Game Informer alumni Thomas Blustin for his tireless work on creating Replay’s new logo, and Joe Kane of Joe Kane Design for the new animated intro. As always, this show wouldn’t be anything special without the video and audio expertise of Ben Hanson and Jason Oestreicher.
Enjoy the episode and please let us know what you think of our new direction in the comments section below!

description: Mario Party is the featured game in the 106th episode of Replay. Due to the length of time they spend on the game, this episode has no second segment.
This episode is hosted by Dan Ryckert and features Joe Juba, Matt Helgeson, and Andrew Reiner, all of whom play.
notes: This "bonus episode", along with Replay: God of War II, aired during the break between Replay's first and second seasons.
Joe had to participate in this Replay due to him losing a bet to the OverBlood Facebook group.
quotes: Mario Party:
Dan: "Hey everyone! I'm Dan Ryckert and I'm the only happy person in this room right now because we're about to play Mario Party."
Joe: "[bleep] you, Dan."
Matt: "Why wouldn't I be happy? It's deadline, I have a lot of work to do, I'm going to be working late tonight, and I'm going to devote an hour and a half of my day to playing Mario Party."
Reiner: "[bleep] you, Dan."
Matt: "I'm taking a zen approach to this. I'm just part of the, the universe."
Joe: "Congratulations Dan, you're an idiot."
Joe: "Dan, you have to understand that the only weapon we have right now is playing this game wrong to spite you."
Matt: "I literally try to do nothing and I'm winning. This is amazing."

Dan: "He put his [bleep] hand over my eyes! Joe, I'm just going to [bleep] on your desk every day I work here for the rest of my life. I'm going to [bleep] on your keyboard and rub it into your [bleep] keys every day."

article.title: Replay – Mario Party
article.author: Dan Ryckert
content: It's happening again. Our longest Replay episode ever was of Mario Party 3, and fans of the show seemed to love watching our agony. My guests never wanted to do another Mario Party episode, but Joe Juba had to go to the Overblood Facebook group and make a bet with them. He lost, and their (and your) reward is yet another episode of Mario Party.

For this go-round, I selected the first entry in the long-running series for Joe, Reiner, Matt, and myself to play. If you're familiar with this particular title, you'll understand completely why the middle of my right palm is sore as I type this. You can see things get predictably ugly below.
(Note: this is not the beginning of Replay season 2. Reiner wanted this to be a "bonus episode" between the two seasons)

description: God of War II is the featured game in the 105th episode of Replay. The Replay Roulette is Ghost Rider.
This episode is hosted by Andrew Reiner and features Jeff Cork, Joe Juba, and Jim Reilly. Joe plays the main game and Roulette.
notes: Reiner didn't like how this episode turned out and initially decided it wouldn't air, but changed his mind and had it posted (along with Replay: Mario Party) during the break between the first and second seasons of Replay.
quotes: God of War II:
Joe: "I'm racist against statues."
Ghost Rider:
Joe: "If you wanna change your elevation, nothing beats stairs! Perhaps escalators."

article.title: Replay – God Of War II
article.author: Dan Ryckert
content: At this point, you can find over 100 episodes of Replay over at our hub page. While we've done a lot of episodes, there are a few finished episodes that you've never seen. On occasion, Reiner will decide after an episode that it's not up to the usual Replay standard, and that episode will be scrapped. A look back at Die Hard Trilogy was discarded during the early days of Replay, and Reiner has also put the axe to odd episodes like Cy Girls, a supremely crappy PS2 title.

Recently, Reiner, Jeff Cork, Joe, and Jim took a look back at God of War II, and Reiner didn't want to air it because he didn't like how it turned out. However, he wanted to end "season one" of Replay and throw in a couple of bonus episodes in the week before we start it up again. That's why this look at God of War II has seen the light of day. I haven't seen it yet myself, so it's up to you to decide if this episode is worthy of the Replay name or whether it should have been tossed into the recycle bin with Die Hard Trilogy and Cy Girls.

secondSegmentGames: Super Mario Bros.: The Lost Levels

description: Super Mario Bros. 2 is the featured game in the 104th episode of Replay. The Replay Roulette is Super Mario Bros.: The Lost Levels.
This episode is hosted by Andrew Reiner and features Matt Helgeson, Dan Ryckert, and Joe Juba. Dan plays the main game and Roulette.
notes: Reiner announced during this episode that this is the end of the first season of Replay. Season two premiered a couple of weeks later with Replay: GoldenEye 007.

Super Mario Bros.: The Lost Levels

article.title: Replay – Super Mario Bros. 2
article.author: Dan Ryckert
content: If you ever read my blog that listed my top ten Mario games, you know I have fond memories of Super Mario Bros. 2. Many gamers don't consider it a "real" Mario game considering that it was originally Doki Doki Panic in Japan, but I say nuts to that. The game is better than the original, and certainly better than the ludicrously hard Japanese Super Mario Bros. 2.

I went into this Replay confident that it would still be a ton of fun, and it didn't disappoint. Watch below as I play the game (and end season 1 of Replay) along with commentary from Andrew Reiner, Joe Juba, and Matt Helgeson.

description: Cold Fear is the featured game in the 103rd episode of Replay. The Replay Roulette is Cold Winter.
This episode is hosted by Andrew Reiner and features Dan Ryckert, Tim Turi, and Phil Kollar. Tim plays the main game and Roulette.

Dan: "You need a knife for sharks. I learned that in OverBlood 2."
Tim: "What if Jim Henson was the main character? Do you think this would have been different?"
Tim: "I now pronounce you... men. With baby."
Cold Winter:
Tim: "Know what they call, uhh, used-up cigarettes on Planet Poop? Poopy butts. They call them poopy butts."

article.title: Replay – Cold Fear
article.author: Dan Ryckert
content: On most episodes of Replay, we pop in a game that one or all of us have some kind of memory of (be it fond or negative). Other times, we grab a random game in the vault that none of us have played (hell, that's how we discovered the now-legendary Overblood). This is one of those other times, as Reiner stumbled upon this PS2 survival horror title and decided to make it this week's Replay.
Will the game satisfy Tim's survival horror fandom? Find out as he plays through Cold Fear with Andrew Reiner, Phil Kollar, and myself.

description: Brave Fencer Musashi is the featured game in the 102nd episode of Replay. The Replay Roulette is the Final Fantasy VIII demo included with Musashi.
This episode is hosted by Jason Oestreicher and features Dan Ryckert, Tim Turi, Jeff Cork and Andrew Reiner. Tim plays both the featured game and the Roulette.

article.title: Replay – Brave Fencer Musashi
article.author: Kyle Hilliard
content: Brave Fencer Musashi came with a demo for Final Fantasy VIII when it originally released, which is probably why many picked up the Sqauresoft (this was before it was SquareEnix) action rpg.
Join Jason Oestreicher, Andrew Reiner, Tim Turi, Dan Ryckert, and Jeff Cork as they make fun of characters with weird triangle faces and play a Replay Roulette like not other.

episodeTitle: Replay: Star Wars: Rebel Assault II: The Hidden Empire

This episode is hosted by Andrew Reiner, and features Bryan Vore, Matt Helgeson, and Jeff Cork.
