article.title: Replay – Boogerman
article.author: Dan Ryckert
content: Some games we play on Replay are undisputed classics, while others are vague memories from our childhoods that may or may not still be good. Boogerman is one of those that I absolutely loved when I was ten years old, but I didn't know exactly what to expect 16 years later. Tim Turi, Joe Juba, Phil Kollar, and myself popped it in recently to find out the answer to that question.
Did Boogerman actually have solid platforming action? More importantly, do boogers and explosive flatulence still make us laugh now that we're older and supposedly more mature? Find out below.

description: Casltevania is the title game for the forty-third episode of Replay. The Replay Roulette for this episode is Mystical Ninja starring Goemon.
The host of this episode is Tim Turi featuring Dan Ryckert, Andrew Reiner, and Bryan Vore.

article.title: Replay – Castlevania 64
article.author: Tim Turi
content: I enjoyed Castlevania 64 for what it was when I was younger. Plugging back in this Nintendo 64 cartridge has proven that age has not been kind to the Castlevania series' first foray into 3D. How many times do we die? How far do we make it into the game? Find out the embarrassing answers to these questions and more.
Join Dan Ryckert, Andrew Reiner, Bryan Vore, and myself as we trek through Transylvania on a quest to slay Dracula... or just make it past the starting area.

description: WWF No Mercy is the title game for the forty-second episode of Replay. The Replay Roulette for this episode is WWF War Zone.
The host of this episode is Dan Ryckert and features Andrew Reiner, Jeff Cork, and Tim Turi.

article.title: Replay – WWF No Mercy
article.author: Dan Ryckert
content: Back in 2000, WWF (not yet WWE) was at the top of its game. Stars like Stone Cold Steve Austin and The Rock had taken "sports entertainment" even higher than Hulk Hogan did in the 80s, and Vince McMahon was raking in cash from t-shirts, tickets, pay-per-views, action figures, and video games. As a huge fan of both wrestling and video games, I couldn't have loved WWF No Mercy any more. It took the awesome, well-established wrestling engine from THQ's previous WWF and WCW games, and added a gigantic roster, new game modes, and more creation options. To this day, I feel that it's the greatest wrestling game ever made.

Check out this week's Replay, where Andrew Reiner, Jeff Cork, Tim Turi, and myself battle in a tag team ladder match. After that, we have Reiner don the referee attire for a one-on-one match between myself and Tim.

description: ObsCure is the title game for the forty-first episode of Replay. The Replay Roulette for this episode is Firefighter F.D. 18.
The host for this episode is Tim Turi and features Andrew Reiner, Jeff Cork, and Jeff Marchiafava.

article.title: Replay – Obscure
article.author: Tim Turi
content: My love of survival horror titles is shared my much of the GI staff. Many of us soaked up every hour of Resident Evil 5's cooperative action, reveling it what many felt was the first true co-op horror experience. DreamCatcher Interactive beat Chris and Sheva to the 2-player punch with the 2004 PlayStation 2 title, Obscure. It features a ragtag crew of high school students as they investigate the death of a fellow student and battle an evil that emerges within their class halls. Is this last generation title a thrilling test of courage or a boring back to school slog?
Join Andrew Reiner, Jeff Cork, and Jeff Marchifava and myself as we enter the dark world of Obscure, and stay tuned for the Replay Roulette afterwords. It really turns up the heat.

description: Swashbucklers: Blue vs. Grey is the title game of the fortieth episode of Replay. The Replay Roulette for this episode is The King of Route 66.
The host for this episode is Tim Turi and features Andrew Reiner, Jeff Cork, and Jeff Marchiafava.

article.title: Replay – Swashbucklers
article.author: Tim Turi
content: Have you heard of Swashbucklers, the 2003 PlayStation 2 title? Neither had we, but we found it in our vault and thought it looked like a worthwhile Replay. Judging this game by its title and cover, we thought we were getting into a mere pirate game. The truth revealed much more... involving schizophrenia, the civil war, corn, mumbling, and more.

This week it's Reiner, Jeff Cork, Jeff Marchiafava, and I at the helm. How far do we get? How much fun is it? How many words does Jeff M utter? Can my pirate voice get any worse? All these questions are answered in the video below...

description: Oddworld: Abe's Oddysee is the title game for the thirty-ninth episode of Replay. The Replay Roulette for this episode is Einhander.
The host for this episode is Joe Juba and features Ben Reeves, Dan Ryckert, and Andrew Reiner.

secondSegmentGames: Sabrina the Teenage Witch: A Twitch in Time

description: Gex: Enter the Gecko is the title game for the thirty-eighth episode of Replay. The Replay Roulette for this episode is Sabrina the Teenage Witch: A Twitch in Time.
The host for this episode is Phil Kollar and features Tim Turi, Ben Reeves, and Andrew Reiner.

external_links.title: Sabrina the Teenage Witch: A Twitch in Time

article.title: Replay – Gex: Enter The Gecko
article.author: Phil Kollar
content: Back in the dark days of the original PlayStation, a secret cabal of the game industry's most talented creators spent a weekend secluded together in a dark catacomb, attempting to concoct an idea for the greatest video game ever (to feature comedian Dana Gould). The result? Gex: Enter the Gecko.

On this week's episode of Replay, Tim Turi, Ben Reeves, Andrew Reiner, and I look back on one of the most popular platformers that has totally faded away in the generations following its release. Does Gex still hold up? (Not exactly.) Will Ben die a bunch? (You know it.) Will any of us survive one of the most atrocious choices for a Replay Roulette yet? (Barely!) Tune in and see for yourself.

description: McDonald's Treasure Land Adventure is the title game for the thirty-seventh episode of Replay. The Replay Roulette for this episode is M.C. Kids and is played on NES.
The host of this episode is Tim Turi and features Jeff Cork, Dan Ryckert, and Phil Kollar.

article.title: Replay – McDonald's Treasure Land Adventure
article.author: Tim Turi
content: Many developers have that single game which stands out from every other title in their lineage. It's not necessarily because it's remarkably good or bad, sometimes it's because it's an odd duckling. A duckling wearing a bright yellow jumpsuit and clown makeup. McDonald's Treasure Land Adventure by Treasure (Ikaruga, Gunstar Heroes, Dynamite Heady, Sin & Punishement) features Ronald McDonald prancing around a whimsical world murdering tiny gnomes and giant bipedal tomatoes with magical death dust. This colorful gem has always stuck out in my head as a good example of an underrated game. Thankfully, we've captured my fellow Game Informer editors berating my childhood taste for quality in the latest Replay.
Come along with Jeff Cork, Dan Ryckert, Phil Kollar, and I as we play this totally not terrible Sega Genesis platformer.

description: Tony Hawk's Pro Skater 2 is the title game for the thirty-sixth episode of Replay. The Replay Roulette for this episode is 2 Xtreme.  It was the first modern game given a Perfect 10 by Game Informer.
The episode is hosted by Dan Ryckert and features Andrew Reiner, Tim Turi, and Jeff Cork.

article.title: Replay – Tony Hawk's Pro Skater 2
article.author: Dan Ryckert
content: While the first Tony Hawk's Pro Skater was a phenomenon, its sequel refined upon everything that made it amazing. With the simple addition of manuals, players were able to link lines and combos together like never before. The series may have drastically declined in quality in recent years, but this Replay proves that there's a reason we all loved the early Tony Hawk games.
Watch Reiner, Tim, Jeff Cork and myself replay the classic below.

description: Mario Party 3 is the title game of the thirty-fifth episode of Replay. Due to its long running time, this installment has no Replay Roulette.
This episode is hosted by Dan Ryckert and features Adam Biessener, Matt Helgeson, and Joe Juba, all of whom play.
notes: At an hour and twenty-four minutes, this is the longest Replay ever aired.
Much to Dan's amusement, Joe and Matt returned for Replay: Mario Party, which was produced as a special episode that aired during the brief hiatus between the first two seasons of Replay.
quotes: Mario Party 3:
Matt: "This game is handicapped."
Joe: "Shut up, Dan."
Joe: (at Tumble) "Ah, I hate that guy."
Joe: "If I can't win, I'm glad Dan lost."
Adam: "What is this, some kind of socialist utopia?"
Joe: "Where are we? This map is terrible!"
Adam: "Oh, God I hate this so much. So much!"
Joe: "Up yours, Mario Party!"
Dan: "It's from my Waluigi fan fiction."
Adam: "You don't read in the swamp, Dan?"
Joe: "Dan was walking around the office like he was some, like, great connoisseur and, like, some daredevil because, like, 'Hey look everyone, I'm eating crickets.'"
Joe: "I'm so good at Mario Party, everyone."
Adam: "Did I say 'interactive'? I meant 'stupid'."
Dan: "Joe looks legitimately angry."
Joe: "Dan, if you come in to work every morning and I punch you in the throat, even if you know it's coming, you don't like it."
Joe: "I just... I wanna die. I wanna die."
Dan: "Oh man, this is going to be a two-hour Replay. These guys are seriously just glaring at me with, like, legitimate anger."
Matt: "This? I hated this game the first time!"
Joe: "I am back with a renewed fury for this game, by the way."
Adam: "I'm still kind of in disbelief that I'm doing this."
Dan: "Everyone, be sure to email joe@gameinformer.com to let him know how much you want to see him on another Mario Party Replay."
Dan: "'Wa Brothers'. I'm coining that. I'm coining that right now."
Dan: "I've never seen Matt Helgeson so angry!"
Adam: "I am flaccid."
Joe: "Up yours, Millennium Star. I hate your mustache."
Joe: "That is the biggest failure I have seen in this game yet, and we've seen so much failure."
Adam: "Can we get a star for hating Dan the most?"
Joe: "Winning Mario Party is like just being the biggest turd in the pile."
Joe: "Dan, you are a first-class idiot."
Adam: "This is like co-operative skeeting."
credit_cookie: Audio clip of Matt threatening to walk out on the Replay; Adam's "I am flaccid" line plays over footage of Adam's utter failure at one of the minigames.

gallery.title: Mario Party 3 - Matt's finger.jpg (221 KB)
gallery.caption: Matt shows his appreciation forMario Party 3... and for Dan.

article.title: Replay – Mario Party 3
article.author: Dan Ryckert
content: "Spending just a measly hour with this miserable, cancer-of-the-brain-inducing game is like going naked hot-tubbing with Rush Limbaugh as your parents cheer and snap photos. I didn't think it was humanly possible for this series to get any worse than it was, but this entry wailed on my unmentionables until they were well past black and blue." - Andrew Reiner, Game Informer issue #128.

If the above quote doesn't spell it out for you clearly enough, Mario Party has a long history of being the most despised series at Game Informer. Hell, Nintendo even sent us a sarcastic plaque commemorating our sheer hatred. I knew it would be a rough experiment, but I rounded up Adam, Matt, and Joe to play through an entire round with me. I also completely forgot how long these rounds are, resulting in our longest Replay ever and the eternal hatred of my co-workers. Check out our misery below.

NOTE: This Replay is crazy long, and it takes an appropriately long time to load. Hit the play button, and if it doesn't start just give it a few minutes. It may take up to 4 or 5 minutes, as it has to load the whole video before it starts.

episodeTitle: Replay: Metroid II: Return of Samus

description: Metroid II: Return of Samus is the title game for the thirty-fourth episode of Replay. The Replay Roulette for this episode is Turbo Turtle Adventure.
The episode is hosted by Phil Kollar and features Tim Turi, Bryan Vore, and Ben Reeves.

external_links.title: Replay: Metroid II: Return of Samus
Replay: Metroid II: Return of Samus

article.title: Replay – Metroid II: Return of Samus
article.author: Phil Kollar
content: You may have read some of the mixed opinions and somewhat controversial reviews (including my own) for Metroid: Other M, the latest adventure starring Nintendo's popular female bounty hunter, Samus. For our first ever Replay featuring a portable game, we decided to take a look back at one of the few the entries in the series that has split fans: Metroid II for GameBoy.

Join Tim Turi, Bryan Vore, Ben Reeves, and I as we load up the GameBoy Color (via the Gamecube's GameBoy Player) and start exterminating a species. Is this NES sequel really as rough as the critics say, or is there still fun to be had with the Return of Samus?

description: Haunting Starring Polterguy is the title game for the thirty-third episode of Replay. The Replay Roulette for this episode is Home Alone.
The host of this episode is Tim Turi and features Andrew Reiner, Joe Juba, and Phil Kollar.

article.title: Replay – Haunting Starring Polterguy
article.author: Tim Turi
content: Here's an often overlooked Genesis classic that revolves around haunting a house until you make the inhabitants homeless. Haunting Starring Polterguy represents a genre that is rarely mimicked in the video game world - possessing crap and scaring the ectoplasm out of people.

Come along with Andrew Reiner, Joe Juba, Phil Kollar, and I as we inhabit household objects like fish tanks, band saws, and rocking chairs in order to terrify the Sardini family out of their lovely home.

description: Urban Chaos: Riot Response is the title game for the thirty-second episode of Replay. The Replay Roulette is Constantine.
The host of this episode is Phil Kollar and features Bryan Vore, Jeff Cork, and Andrew Reiner.

article.title: Replay – Urban Chaos
article.author: Phil Kollar
content: I'm sure I wasn't the only gamer who played Batman: Arkham Asylum last year, loved it, and thought to myself, "Where did these Rocksteady guys come from?!" Though it's largely been forgotten, the team at Rockstead did create one game before last year's huge success: Urban Chaos: Riot Response, a 2006 first-person shooter for the Xbox and PlayStation 2.

As the final piece of our month of Batman: Arkham City coverage online, we decided to revisit Rocksteady's past. Join Bryan Vore, Jeff Cork, Andrew Reiner, and I as we team up with firefighters, cops, and medics to take down a gang and save...my mom? Uh, just check out the video below.

description: Syphon Filter  is the title game for the thirty-first episode of Replay. The Replay Roulette is Quake II.
The episode is hosted by Tim Turi and features Andrew Reiner, Dan Ryckert, and Phil Kollar.

article.title: Replay – Syphon Filter
article.author: Tim Turi
content: A lot has happened to the action genre over the past decade, but there's no better way to appreciate the advancements of running and gunning than looking back at games from past generations. Syphon Filter is an action/ stealth hybrid that released on PlayStation a year after Metal Gear Solid hit the console. It came to glory when stealth games were booming, but its focus on intense firefights and objective-based missions separated it from the pack. So, how has it aged?

Come along with Replay regulars Andrew Reiner, Dan Ryckert, Phil Kollar, and I as we pop in the original Syphon Filter, a game which spurred on a series of PlayStation, PlayStation 2, and PSP games. And trust me, we get through the entire episode without making any "don't taze me, bro!" jokes. At least, I think we do...

description: The Smurfs  is the title game of the thirtieth episode of Replay. This Replay Roulette for this episode is Smurf Racer.
The host for this episode is Phil Kollar and features Andrew Reiner, Joe Juba, and Ben Reeves.

article.title: Replay – The Smurfs
article.author: Phil Kollar
content: Sometimes on Replay, we pull out and revisit old classics. Sometimes we pick out games that we know are terrible. And sometimes, we stumble across anomalies in the Vault that begs to be explained. This week is the latter. While digging through GI's massive game collection, I came across a copy of The Smurfs for PlayStation, and I invited Andrew Reiner, Joe Juba, and Ben Reeves to check it out.
Join us as we ponder where Smurfs come from, mock Ben's questionable gameplay decisions, and use "smurfed" as a stand-in for words that we'd normally replace with a Mario jumping sound effect.

description: StarCraft 64 is the titel game for the twenty-ninth episode of Replay. The Replay Roulette for this episode is Paperboy
This episode is hosted by Phil Kollar and features Andrew Reiner, Dan Ryckert, and Adam Biessener.

article.title: Replay – StarCraft 64
article.author: Phil Kollar
content: A good chunk of the Game Informer staff has spent the last couple of weeks infatuated with StarCraft II, the latest real-time strategy epic from Blizzard. While many of us have fond memories of the original StarCraft from 1998, there's probably a lot less people who remember 2000's Nintendo 64 port. Luckily, we do, and we decided to dig it out of the vault and check it out.

Join Andrew Reiner, Dan Ryckert, Adam Biessener, and I as we attempt to figure out what's going on with StarCraft 64's muddy graphics and sound, discuss Dan's Southern/swamp heritage, and explore an altogether different ruining of a different classic game from days past in Replay Roulette.

description: Revolution X is the name of the 28th episode of Replay. It was posted to the Game Informer Website on July 31, 2010.

Revolution X is one of the most famous episodes of Replay as a result of its Roulette, OverBlood, which would become one of the most popular and well-regarded Super Replays on the site. The Revolution X episode of Replay was selected by the Replay crew as their favorite episode of Replay not only for being the "birthplace of OverBlood" but for being a generally "fantastic" episode lampooning a "ridiculous" game.
This episode is hosted by Dan Ryckert and features Replay regulars Andrew Reiner and Tim Turi (alternating on controls) as well as guest Matt Helgeson.
quotes: Revolution X:
"I have it on good authority that if a helecopter is off balance, it goes down." - Tim Turi
"You are a game journalist, not a geographer..." - Tim Turi
"Aerosmith's Car...cool!" - Revolution X
"This is like Mass Effect" - Matt Helgeson
"It's totally like a pedophile Osama Bin Laden" - Matt Helgeson
Overblood:
"What is going on?!" - Andrew Reiner
"Need nore blue" - Tim Turi
trivia: Matt Helgeson was on call during this episode. The reason was that he was waiting to hear from his wife, who was expected to go into labor any day.

external_links.title: Our Ten Favorite Episodes of Replay

system: Arcade, SNES, Mega Drive/Genesis, PC, Sega Saturn, PlayStation

article.title: Our Ten Favorite Episodes Of Replay
article.author: Dan Ryckert
content: We've been doing Replay for two years now, and in the course of the series we've played over 100 games. Some of the best games of all time have received the Replay treatment, and so have some of the worst. To celebrate the beginning of our second season of Replay (beginning tomorrow), the crew has put together a list of our ten favorite episodes of all time.

Reiner, Tim, and myself also sat down to discuss the creation of Replay, some anecdotes you may not know about, and some hints at what the future holds. You can listen to it here or download it from the file attachment link at the bottom of the page:
[View:http://media1.gameinformer.com/media/audio/theshow/replayhistory/historyreplay2.mp3:610]
Now on to the list!
Reader's Pick: Mario Party 3Cast: Dan Ryckert, Joe Juba, Matt Helgeson, Adam Biessener

description: Medal of Honor  is the title game for the twenty-seventh episode of Replay. The Replay Roulette is The Crow: City of Angels.
This episode is hosted by Dan Ryckert and features Andrew Reiner, Tim Turi, and Nick Ahrens.

article.title: Replay – Medal of Honor
article.author: Dan Ryckert
content: We may be 65 years removed from World War II, but gamers have spent much of the last decade shooting Nazis like it was 1944 all over again. With the numerous games spanning the massive conflict, FPS gamers eventually became burned out on the concept. However, we hadn't experienced anything like it before Medal of Honor released in 1999. Unless you count shooting Mecha-Hitler in Wolfenstein 3D, that is.

Half-Life may have already been making waves and revolutionizing the FPS genre on the PC side of things, but console gamers were just starting to get their first real taste of it. Goldeneye 007 was a massive hit, but EA's Medal of Honor was one of the first to base its gameplay around real historical events. With Saving Private Ryan still fresh in movie fan's minds and Steven Spielberg helping out with the story, their timing couldn't have been more perfect for the first big WWII FPS. Check out the video below to see Andrew Reiner, Tim Turi, Nick Ahrens and myself take on the Third Reich all over again.

description: Enter the Matrix is the title game of the twenty-sixth episode of Replay. The Replay Roulette is Starsky and Hutch.
This episode is hosted by Phil Kollar and features Joe Juba, Tim Turi, and Andrew Reiner.

article.title: Replay – Enter The Matrix
article.author: Phil Kollar
content: Back when Enter the Matrix was announced, it was a potential revolution -- a movie-based game that actually had most of the talent from the movie, including the writers/directors, fully involved. How did it turn out? On this week's episode of Replay, Joe Juba, Tim Turi, Andrew Reiner, and I dig it out of the vault to find out.

Watch the video below to hear Reiner's reasoning behind the rather high score he gave the game, listen to discussion of Miller's love of the Matrix universe, and see two cars stand up and fight like men. If you're well-behaved (and patient), you might even get blessed with a snippet of song from Tim.

description: Tomb Raider is the title game of the twenty-fifth episode of Replay. The Replay Roulette is Cool Boarders 2.

This episode is hosted by Meagan Marie and features Tim Turi, Dan Ryckert, and Andrew Reiner. Meagan plays the featured game, while Dan plays a track on Roulette and hands off the controller to Meagan later on.
notes: This is the only Replay hosted by Meagan Marie. She hosted the Tomb Raider episode because she is quoted as saying, "I had an unhealthy obsession with this game through most of my childhood."

article.title: Replay – Tomb Raider
article.author: Meagan Marie
content: The cyber it-girl of the late 90s, Lara Croft’s debut wowed gamers with cutting edge graphics, ingenious level design, engaging puzzles, and an atmospheric soundtrack. Despite the well-deserved accolades, the original Tomb Raider’s legacy and success remains inextricably tied to one pony-tailed heroine – now the most recognized female face in gaming. Lady Lara Croft blossomed into a  phenomena of her own, and despite waning franchise popularity throughout the years, it’s impossible to deny the massive fallout Tomb Raider’s debut title had across the industry.Being a bit of a Tomb Raider junkie, I host my first Replay episode to see if time has been gentle to Croft’s official unveiling. Joined by fellow editors Tim Turi, Dan Rykert, and Andy Reiner, we sample some of Tomb Raider’s most iconic levels and reminisce about the many entertaining ways Croft can meet her demise.  Also, stick around for our weekly Replay Roulette. On the docket this episode is Cool Boarders 2. This one…is a bit painful.Enjoy!

description: Mister Mosquito is the title game of the twenty-fourth episode of Replay. The Replay Roulette is PO'ed.
This episode is hosted by Dan and features Tim, Joe, and Reiner. Dan and Joe take turns playing the featured game while Joe and Tim alternate playing the Roulette.
notes: This is one of the few instances of a Roulette being for a different system than the main game; Mister Mosquito is a PS2 game while PO'ed is for the original PlayStation.

article.title: Replay – Mister Mosquito
article.author: Dan Ryckert
content: When Eidos launched its Fresh Games label during the Playstation 2 era, their goal was to bring quirky, obscure Japanese titles to US shores. The label didn't last very long, but we can at least be thankful that it brought the fantastically weird Mister Mosquito stateside. We explore that strange game on this week's episode of Replay.

You play as the titular insect, and (as you can imagine) your duties as a mosquito involve sucking as much blood as possible from unwilling humans. And by humans, I'm specifically referring to the unfortunate Yamato family. Watch below as Andrew Reiner, Tim Turi, Joe Juba, and myself terrorize this innocent family's summer.

description: Batman: Dark Tomorrow is the featured game in the 23rd episode of Replay. The Replay Roulette for this episode features Teen Titans.
This episode is hosted by Phil Kollar, and features Dan Ryckert, Jeff Cork, and Andrew Reiner.

article.title: Replay – Batman: Dark Tomorrow
article.author: Phil Kollar
content: And I thought Superman 64 was bad. On this week's episode of Replay, Dan Ryckert, Andrew Reiner, and Jeff Cork join me in my ongoing quest to play every awful superhero game ever...and boy, is this Gamecube-era Kemco release awful. Witness our breath-taking attempts to leap across the roofs of Gotham and stop crime with unstoppable smoke capsules. This isn't going to end well.
Enjoy the full show below, stay tuned after for a special sidekick-themed Replay Roulette, and check out more episodes at our Replay hub.

description: "You got a 'Dan'," Reiner, upon seeing Joe's D Grade
Devil May Cry is the featured game in this episode of Replay. Dan Ryckert takes the role as the host, with Tim Turi, Andrew Reiner, and Joe Juba as guests.

The episode starts with Mission 2 of Devil May Cry, with Joe at the controls. Most of the episode, Reiner berates Dan's skills at Devil May Cry, mocking him having trouble on the first mission. Joe joins in, and the two ridicule Dan's practice of using the guns over any other weapon. Together, Joe is able to complete the mission, and the next mission.

For the Roulette, they play Fugitive Hunter: War on Terror. Tim Turi is at the controls, and has difficulty controlling the game. After a brief first-person-shooter level, the game switches to a 2D fighter. This change up, and the game's poor fighting method proves to be hilarious to the crew. After capturing one terrorist in the game, they end the episode.
credits_cookies: When Dan was giving the outro, he slurred "War on Terror" with the word "Here" and the rest of the crew thought he said "War on Terrier". Dan even repeats the phrase a couple of times, being admitting to maybe have saying "Terrier". If you listen very closely, you should be able to hear the sentence.

article.title: Replay – Devil May Cry
article.author: Dan Ryckert
content: Dante may not have been the first hero to wield a gun and a sword at the same time (see: Rising Zan), but he certainly did it with the most style. Devil May Cry started its production as a Resident Evil game, but the game took such a drastic gameplay departure that it was rebranded as its own series. Rather than the slow-paced nature and atmosphere popularized by the early RE games, DMC was all about fast-paced, flashy action. It's hard to forget the first time you saw Dante launch an enemy into the air with his sword and then keep him there with a flurry of pistol shots.
Take a look at our Replay below as Joe Juba, Andrew Reiner, Tim Turi, and myself revisit Dante's first adventure.

description: Grabbed by the Ghoulies is the featured game in the 21st episode of Replay. The Replay Roulette for this episode features Dragon's Lair 3D: Return to the Lair.
This episode is hosted by Phil Kollar, and features Andrew Reiner, Dan Ryckert, and Tim Turi.

external_links.title: Dragon's Lair 3D: Return to the Lair

article.title: Replay – Grabbed By The Ghoulies
article.author: Phil Kollar
content: In this week's episode of Replay, I refer to Rare's Xbox-era beat-em-up Grabbed by the Ghoulies as a "classic" on several occasions. My love of Rare aside, let it be known that Grabbed by the Ghoulies is not, in reality, a classic. What went wrong with Rare's first game for Microsoft? Andrew Reiner, Dan Ryckert, and Tim Turi join me to find out.
Watch the full episode below and then head on over to the Replay hub to view all our past Replays.

description: Dino Crisis is the title game of the twentieth episode of Replay. The Replay Roulette is Muppet Monster Adventure.
This episode is hosted by Phil Kollar and features Tim Turi, Jeff Cork, and Andrew Reiner. Phil and Tim play the featured game while Jeff and Tim play the Roulette.
credit_cookie: Brief gameplay from Dino Crisis, followed by gameplay from Muppet Monster Adventure in which Tim jumps off a bridge that Jeff fell off of and says, "Look at me, I'm Jeff."

article.title: Replay – Dino Crisis
article.author: Phil Kollar
content: We've got a lot of survival horror fans in the office, so you can imagine how psyched we were to dig into Capcom's dinosaur-based Resident Evil clone, Dino Crisis, when it first came out in 1999. But how does the pixelated action hold up today? I'm joined by Andrew Reiner, Jeff Cork, and Tim Turi to find out. Let's just say we find a lot more keycards and a lot less dinosaurs than we might have expected.
Watch the video below, and when you're done, check out our Replay Hub for all of our past episodes.

description: Pokémon Snap is the featured game in the 19th episode of Replay. The Replay Roulette for this episode features Elmo's Number Journey.
This episode is hosted by Tim Turi, and features Andrew Reiner, Dan Ryckert, and Phil Kollar.

article.title: Replay – Pokémon Snap
article.author: Tim Turi
content: Since its inception in1996, Pokémon has remained relevant in gaming culture. Of course the fanatic fervor has calmed since the late 90s, but I still remember a time when each new Pikachu-branded product made me feel warm and fuzzy. Pokémon Snap, a photography game for the N64 was one of those surprising spin-offs that proved to be just as much fun as the main entries. For this weeks Replay, we take a look back at the on-rails shutterbug shooter.

Join Andrew Reiner, Dan Ryckert, Phil Kollar, and I as we travel across Professor Oak's natural Pokémon habitat. We cruise the beach, a river, and even a fiery volcano in search of shots that outshine the photographs already saved onto the dusty N64 cartridge. Keep your eyes peeled for marvels like incapacitated Charmeleons, infuriatingly stupid Slowpokes, and emotionally confused Magmars. Remember to stay tuned after the Pokémon Snap Replay for an extra special, and extra educational Replay Roulette. (Be patient, the video takes a minute or two to load).

episodeTitle: Replay: Rising Zan: The Samurai Gunman

description: Rising Zan: The Samurai Gunman is the title game of the eighteenth episode of Replay. The Replay Roulette is Spice World.
This episode is hosted by Dan Ryckert and features Andrew Reiner, Tim Turi, and Bryan Vore. Dan plays the main game (Tim helps) while Tim plays the Roulette.
notes: Tim spends just under four minutes playing Spice World, making it one of the shortest ever Roulettes.
quotes: Rising Zan:
Tim: "'Come inside the church so I can give you a spanking.' Some sort of commentary going on here about religion."
Dan: "I got thirty-four hundred sexy points."
Spice World:
Dan: "Ladies and gentlemen, welcome to the worst Replay Roulette we've ever done."

external_links.title: Replay: Rising Zan: The Samurai Gunman
Replay: Rising Zan: The Samurai Gunman

article.title: Replay – Rising Zan: Samurai Gunman
article.author: Dan Ryckert
content: Odds are, you have never heard of this game. If you haven't, this Replay is for you. Rising Zan: Samurai Gunman was released in 1999 for the PSone, and to this day is one of the most ridiculous games ever made.

You play as Zan (formerly Johnny, now "Johnny No More"), an American cowboy who travels east to learn the way of the samurai. When he returns to the west, he uses his newfound skills to murder ninjas, Russian nesting dolls, sumo wrestlers, and evil crucifixes made of hay. Watch below as myself, Tim Turi, Andrew Reiner, and Bryan Vore play through this brilliantly absurd title. And just try to get the unbelievable theme song out of your head.

description: Final Fight: Streetwise is the featured game in the 17th episode of Replay. The Replay Roulette for this episode features Rune: Viking Warlord.
This episode is hosted by Bryan Vore, and features Jeff Cork, Joe Juba, and Dan Ryckert.

article.title: Replay – Final Fight: Streetwise
article.author: Bryan Vore
content: While some may complain that a PS2 game released in 2006 is too recent for Replay, I would argue that Final Fight: Streetwise plays just as bad as a game from the late '90s.Made by Capcom Production Studio 8, this game contributed greatly to the American studio's closing that same year. After witnessing how terribly Streetwise handles the franchise, it's easy to see why. Join myself, Jeff Cork, Joe Juba, and Dan Ryckert as we stomp loads of gang members... and roaches. Watch out for some rough language from the streets courtesy of the Mad Gear.

description: Super Mario Sunshine

In this episode, the Replay Crew plays Super Mario Sunshine for the Nintendo GameCube. The game is set in a resort island known as Delfino Island. Mario must clear his name by cleaning up the polution Shadow Mario has created.

As they pass the controller around, the crew also tries to figure out why Super Mario Sunshine was not as well recieved as the other 3-D Mario games. This is the first time Riener has seen Dan "be good with video games." Throughout the Mario Sunshine segment, Tim, Dan, and Reiner also list things Phil hates, including ice cream, Terminator 2, and water slides.
The segment ends with Tim grasping a Shine Sprite, and Phil muttering under his breath, "I still hate it."
WWE Crush Hour

A game seemingly made for Dan Ryckert, WWE Crush Hour is a demolition derby style game made for the Playstation 2 and Nintendo GameCube. Vince McMahon has gained control of every television network, filling them up with shows starring professional wrestlers. His latest creation, Crush Hour pits wrestlers against each other in vehicles filled with weapons to annihilate the competition. The objective is to gain as many points as possible by destroying the other cars.
The crew passes the controller between Dan and Tim as they tried to win a match. The roullette ends with a loss, not that Tim minds.
post_credits_cookie: Dan edits Phil's audioclips to repeatedly say, "I hate it. I don't hate it. I hate it. I don't hate it."
trivia: Dan rates Super Mario Sunshine above The Legend of Zelda: Wind Waker
Phil Kollar addresses that Super Mario Galaxy is the only 3-D Mario game he likes (as of the recording date).
This is the first time a Mario game has been shown on an episode of Replay.
This is also the most recent Mario game that has been featured on an episode of Replay or Super Replay.
quotes: Super Mario Sunshine:
Dan: "...You get rocket nozzles, and turbo nozzles later and you can switch it to this one."
Tim: "I just got past a bad case of the 'rocket nozzles."
Tim "That is a tangent."
WWE Crush Hour:
Tim "More like Generico."
Tim "It's an intimidation laser."
Dan "Was Booker T shooting cookies at you?"
Tim "There's no cusp, it's a log."

article.title: Replay – Super Mario Sunshine
article.author: Dan Ryckert
content: When it released in 2002, critics almost unanimously praised Super Mario Sunshine for its fantastic level design, beautiful visuals, and wealth of new moves thanks to Mario's FLUDD device. However, it's far more polarizing than the games directly preceding and following it (64 and Galaxy). Regardless of your feelings on this entry in the series, Nintendo has made it clear that they consider it part of the franchise's legacy. You'll see Sunshine-based stages in Mario Kart and Smash Bros, and characters like Toadsworth and the Piantas have stuck around to this day.

What is it that caused this particular game to be such a divisive entry in the franchise's long history? Watch this week's Replay to see myself, Andrew Reiner, Tim Turi, and Phil Kollar revisit the plumber's only Gamecube platformer.

description: Zombie Revenge is the title game of the fifteenth episode of Replay. The Replay Roulette is Maken X.
This episode is hosted by Tim Turi and features Andrew Reiner, Dan Ryckert, and Phil Kollar. Reiner and Dan play the main game while Phil plays the Roulette.
quotes: Zombie Revenge:
Tim: "Strobe light mode for no damn reason."
Dan: "Why do I run with my arms behind me like a chicken?"
credit_cookie: Someone (Reiner?) performs a rather weak rendition of the old Sega logo call.

article.title: Replay – Zombie Revenge
article.author: Tim Turi
content: Zombies, zombies, zombies!!! The undead are all the rage these days, but long before the zombie renaissance Sega unleashed Zombie Revenge in 2000 on the Dreamcast. The game is set in Sega's House of the Dead series, but apparently it's questionable quality held it back from donning the prestigious brand. Join us as a brave young man named Stick fist fights his way through hordes of zombies.

Yours truly hosts this edition of Replay with guests Dan Ryckert, Phil Kollar, and Andrew Reiner. In this episode we answer the tough questions like: what color is zombie blood? What sort of security systems do sewers have? And would Reiner or Dan win a fist fight during the zombie apocalypse? Watch the video below to learn the truth.

episodeTitle: Replay: Blood Omen: Legacy of Kain

description: In season one, episode 14 of Replay, host Phil Kollar and co- hosts Andrew Reiner , Ben Reeves and Joe Juba play the 1996 title Blood Omen: Legacy of Kain for PlayStation.

external_links.title: Replay: Blood Omen: Legacy of Kain
Replay: Blood Omen: Legacy of Kain

article.title: Replay – Blood Omen: Legacy of Kain
article.author: Phil Kollar
content: In this week's replay, we explore the humble (and kind of sluggish) beginnings to a long-forgotten franchise that once held a special place in our hearts. Join me, Andrew Reiner, Ben Reeves, and Joe Juba as we boot up the PlayStation action-RPG Blood Omen: Legacy of Kain. And as always, stay tuned after we move on from our Kain discussion for a bonus Replay Roulette with a slightly less memorable PS1 game from GI's vault.

description: Superman (colloquially known as Superman 64) is the title game of the thirteenth episode of Replay. The Replay Roulette is the NES Superman.
This episode is hosted by Phil Kollar and features Andrew Reiner, Joe Juba, and Tim Turi, all of whom play the featured game while Joe plays the Roulette.
notes: This is one of the few instances of switching to a different system for the Roulette; the main game is for N64 while the Roulette is an NES game.
quotes: Superman: The New Superman Adventures:
Phil: "You will believe a man can fly... through rings."
Reiner: "I'm doing the N64 flick to get a little better speed."
Joe: "I'm having trouble understanding what's happening here."
Tim: "I've seen my grandpa get up faster after falling down."
Phil: "Let's look at this and then let's never talk about this game ever again."
Tim: "I'm stuck. I can't move. I can't move at all. You just sit still while you get shot. The game– what kind of game is this? This game is worse than Superman 6– ugh!"
Superman:
Joe: "So here we have Superman, well known for taking orders from his boss: the Statue of Liberty."
Joe: "I'm hitting A and, like, I guess that's the totally spaz out button."
Joe: "I'm Superman! I will destroy your subway!"

article.title: Replay – Superman 64
article.author: Phil Kollar
content: Look, up in the air! It's a bird! It's a plane! It's...a bunch of disgruntled editors playing one of the worst video games ever created. In our recurring exploration of all the old games packed into Game Informer's vault, it was inevitable that we attempt to take on Superman 64, one of the most infamous development disasters of all time.

So is it really as bad as everyone says? Did I actually spend a whole day playing the first level over and over in order to unlock the level select? Will anyone laugh at my "You will believe a man can fly" joke? Join me, Tim Turi, Andrew Reiner, and Joe Juba as we dust off the N64 and submit ourselves to 20 minutes of torture just for you. And be sure to stay tuned after the main feature for a look at the earlier adventures of Clark Kent in Replay Roulette.

description: Earthworm Jim is the title game of the twelfth episode of Replay. The Replay Roulette is Pinocchio.
This episode is hosted by Phil Kollar and features Dan Ryckert, Andrew Reiner, and Tim Turi. Tim, Reiner, and Dan play the featured game while Tim plays the Roulette.
quotes: Tim "Yeah Petey was a son of a B."
Tim "Oh you silly silly trash monster."
Pinocchio
Reiner "Hats off to Geppetto for making a really agile boy"
Dan "I wouldn't peg Pinocchio as being Metriod esque."
Phill "Here's some tips that the game gives 'Always chose the path of truth'." Tim "That was back there I think I should've taken a left before."
credit_cookie: Earthworm Jim gameplay showing the cow fall into lava and Jim steal the queen's crown.

article.title: Replay – Earthworm Jim
article.author: Phil Kollar
content: Some games continue to shine years after their release, some fail to hold up, and some land squarely in the middle. We're exploring the latter territory on this week's episode of Replay, where we tackle Earthworm Jim, a wonderfully quirky platformer that has fantastic animation and tons of charm with some slightly less-than-ideal actual platforming.

Join me, Tim Turi, Dan Ryckert, and Andrew Reiner in playing through multiple levels of this Shiny classic, including the infamous "For Pete's Sake." And stay tuned after the cow drops for another edition of Replay Roulette, where we grab a random SNES game from our vault and see how long it holds our attention.

description: Spyro the Dragon is the name of the eleventh episode of Replay. The Replay Roulette is Future Cop LAPD.
This episode is hosted by Tim Turi and features Andrew Reiner and Phil Kollar. Tim plays a majority of the featured game, with Reiner and Phil trying a few levels. Reiner plays the Roulette,
notes: This Replay is one of the few that does not follow the standard "One host, three guests" format. No particular reason is given.
quotes: Spyro the Dragon
Reiner: "You go with, like, Jason Statham or something like that. You don't pick Elijah Wood when to try to mature something."
Future Cop LAPD

Tim: "It looks like we're looking at an...Oh, boy."
Reiner: "Is this, like, a Star Trek convention? Look at all these outfits."
Tim: "I'll tell ya, this game belongs in the trash can."

article.title: Replay – Spyro The Dragon
article.author: Tim Turi
content: Before Ratchet and Clank, before Resistance: Fall of Man, there was Spyro. The first Spyro the Dragon put developer Insomniac games on the map, and gave established Sony mascot Crash Bandicoot a run for his money. For this edition of replay we cruise around the introductory levels, reminisce on our good and not-so-good memories of the franchise, and even offer up some interesting facts about the game.Join myself, Andrew Reiner, and Phil Kollar as we assume the role of the spunky purple dragon in an attempt to see how his game has aged. Is this 12 year-old title still worth checking out?

description: Blaster Master is the tenth episode of Replay. The Replay Roulette is Disaster Report.
This episode is hosted by Phil Kollar and features Matt Miller, Andrew Reiner, and Jeff Marchiafava. Phil, Reiner, and Matt play the featured game, while Reiner and Matt play the Roulette.
notes: This is an instance where the featured game and the Roulette are from two different consoles. Blaster Master is an NES title, whereas Disaster Report is on the Playstation 2.
Jeff is given the nickname "The Fav" in this episode, much to his annoyance.

article.title: Replay – Blaster Master
article.author: Phil Kollar
content: Every so often, while browsing GI's massive vault, I stumble across games that helped define my childhood but that I had somehow forgotten about completely. Blaster Master for NES was just one such game. Radioactive pet frogs? A powerful tank that also jumps? What else could a kid ask for?

Join myself, Matt Miller, Andrew Reiner, and Jeff "The Fav" Marchiafava in looking back to see how well this game that I have such fond memories of has held up. The full video (including a bonus Replay Roulette) is below.

description: Mortal Kombat Mythologies: Sub-Zero is the title game of the ninth episode of Replay. The Replay Roulette is Wu-Tang: Shaolin Style.

This episode is notable for having a different cast of editors for the featured game and the Roulette. The main game is hosted by Dan Ryckert and features Ben Reeves, Bryan Vore, and Tim Turi. Everyone takes turns playing the featured game.
The Roulette is hosted by Dan Ryckert and features Matt Helgeson, Annette Gonzalez, and Tim Turi. Everyone gets a chance to play the Roulette.

Matt Helgeson and Annette Gonzalez are self-proclaimed Wu-Tang Clan fans.

This is the start of long tradition of the Replay crew asking for audience participation for a given project. This would later lead to a number of competitions for t-shirt designs after Super Replays.

article.title: Replay – Mortal Kombat Mythologies: Sub-Zero
article.author: Dan Ryckert
content: Here on Replay, you've seen us take a look back at both great andnot-so-great titles. If there was ever one to fall into the lattergroup, this is it. Mortal Kombat Mythologies: Sub-Zero is unanimouslyconsidered by all sane gamers to be absolutely terrible. Everythingfrom the controls to the cutscenes comes from the very bottom of thegaming barrel, but that won't stop us from revisiting this wretchedtitle.Check out the video below to watch myself, Tim Turi, BenReeves, and Bryan Vore die an absurd amount of times and curse its very existence. And please,someone out there...turn the "Sub-Zero falling" animation into a .gif.

description: ActRaiser is the title of the eighth episode of Replay. The Replay Roulette is Incredible Crisis.

This episode is notable for having a two different cast of editors playing the featured game and the Roulette. The main game his hosted by Bryan Vore and features Joe Juba, Tim Turi, and Phil Kollar. Bryan Vore plays the feature game.
A new crew is brought in for the Roulette with Phil Kollar hosting, and features Andrew Reiner, Matt Miller, and Jeff Marchiafava. Reiner and Jeff trade the controller while playing.

This episode is the debut of Bryan Vore, Matt Miller and Jeff Marchiafava on Replay.
Phil had never played the featured game, and Joe and Bryan had extensive childhood memories with it. Tim had played it later on the Virtual Console.
The silent Roulette intro happens again in this episode before Incredible Crisis.

article.title: Replay – Actraiser
article.author: Dan Ryckert
content: For this week’s Replay we dive into 1991’s genre mash-up Actraiser. Combining town management aspects and 2D side-scrolling action, the game offers a glimpse back to a time when games were less restricted to specific genres. Join Joe Juba, Tim Turi, Ben Reeves, and Replay newcomer Bryan Vore as they reminisce on this 16-bit classic.

description: Turok: Dinosaur Hunter is the title of the seventh episode of Replay. The Replay Roulette is Tonic Trouble.

This episode is hosted by Andrew Reiner and features Dan Ryckert, Tim Turi, and Ben Reeves. Reiner plays the featured game, passing the controller to Dan midway through. Ben begins playing the Roulette, but Tim takes the controller away halfway through.

Reiner reviewed Turok: Dinosaur Hunter in the March 1997 issue of Game Informer. He gave the game a 9.5 out of 10.
"Turok is a sure fire hit in every category, and a must have for all N64 owners, game addicts, and beginners who want to see the most impressive graphics display on the planet."[1]

article.title: Replay – Turok
article.author: Dan Ryckert
content: We always check our comments to see what games you'd like to seefeatured in Replay, and this week's selection is one that's beenrequested many times. Turok: Dinosaur Hunter was released on February28th of 1997, and was met with critical and commercial success. At thisearly point in the Nintendo 64's life, games were scarce and shooterseven moreso. The 64-bit FPS crown was handed over to Goldeneye laterthat year, but many gamers still have fond memories of raptor murderand awkward platforming. Take a look at the newest edition of Replaybelow to see how Turok has stood the test of time.

description: Apocalypse is the title game of the sixth episode of Replay. The Replay Roulette is The Simpsons Wrestling.

article.title: Replay – Apocalypse
article.author: Dan Ryckert
content: It's not uncommon these days to see big name movie stars appear in video game form. Samuel L. Jackson, Martin Sheen, James Woods, and Liam Neeson have lent their voices to games in the last decade, and many more have lent their likenesses. However, the man who brought you John McClane was ahead of the curve in 1998 when he starred in Apocalypse for the PSone. Check out our look back at 32-bit Bruce, along with a particularly awful Replay Roulette.

description: DuckTales is the title of the fifth episode of Replay. The Replay Roulette is Yo! Noid. Mad Max is played as a bonus Roulette game.

The episode is hosted by Phil Kollar and features Dan Ryckert, Tim Turi, and Andrew Reiner. Tim plays the featured game, passing the controller to Reiner after one death. After getting stuck, they switch to DuckTales 2 which Tim plays. Dan plays both the Roulette and Bonus Roulette games.

This is the second episode with a silent Roulette intro. The first being Star Wars: Masters of Teräs Käsi.

DuckTales is the first NES game to be featured on Replay.

article.title: Replay – DuckTales
article.author: Dan Ryckert
content: We've been getting a lot of requests in the comment sections of Replay, and many of you mentioned that you'd like to see some NES titles. We figure most gamers have a pretty clear memory of the obvious choices (Mario, Zelda, Punch-Out) thanks to re-releases, emulators, and the Virtual Console, so we landed on Scrooge McDuck's treasure-hunting adventures. It was well-received when it was released and many gamers have feelings of nostalgia for it, but how does the gameplay hold up two decades later? Check out the new episode below and just try to get the cartoon's theme out of your head.
Want to watch more episodes of Replay? Visit our Replay hub page to view them all!

article.title: Replay – Star Wars Masters Of Teras Kasi
article.author: Dan Ryckert
content: The demographic crossover between video game fans and Star Wars fans is an unsurprising one. However, the gaming interpretations of the galaxy far, far away have suffered from a very spotty history. For every Knights of the Old Republic or Rogue Squadron, there's a Super Bombad Racing or Jedi Power Battles. Despite some who may have enjoyed 1997's Star Wars fighter, Masters of Teras Kasi falls into the latter group for most gamers. Check out our newest edition of Replay below to hear myself, Andrew Reiner, Tim Turi, and Joe Juba play and reminisce over a game that most of us didn't necessarily have the fondest memories of.

description: Jaws Unleashed is the title game of the third episode of Replay. The Replay Roulette is Azurik: Rise of Perathia.
This episode is hosted by Phil Kollar and features Dan Ryckert, Andrew Reiner, and Tim Turi. Andrew plays the featured game while Dan plays the Roulette, passing the controller to Tim midway through.

This episode came in at number 5 of Game Informer's "Top Ten Episodes of Replay" feature.
Dan reviewed Jaws Unleashed during college for Lawrence.com and gave the game a 6.9 out of 10.
"Worth a rental at least for fans of the film or senseless destruction."[1]
Reiner also reviewed Jaws Unleashed, but for Game Informer. He gave the game a 4.75 out of 10.
"After this miserable showing, the only waters that Jaws will be patrolling are those of the great video game toilet."[2]

article.title: Our Ten Favorite Episodes Of Replay
article.author: Dan Ryckert
content: We've been doing Replay for two years now, and in the course of the series we've played over 100 games. Some of the best games of all time have received the Replay treatment, and so have some of the worst. To celebrate the beginning of our second season of Replay (beginning tomorrow), the crew has put together a list of our ten favorite episodes of all time.

Reiner, Tim, and myself also sat down to discuss the creation of Replay, some anecdotes you may not know about, and some hints at what the future holds. You can listen to it here or download it from the file attachment link at the bottom of the page:
[View:http://media1.gameinformer.com/media/audio/theshow/replayhistory/historyreplay2.mp3:610]
Now on to the list!
Reader's Pick: Mario Party 3Cast: Dan Ryckert, Joe Juba, Matt Helgeson, Adam Biessener

description: Bushido Blade is the title game of the second episode of Replay. This is the debut of the Replay Roulette, which featured NBA Live '96.

This episode is hosted by Dan Ryckert and features Phil Kollar, Jeff Cork, and Andrew Reiner. The crew takes turns playing the featured game, passing the controller on death. Phil and Reiner go head-to-head in the Roulette.
notes: This is the inaugural episode of Replay Roulette, where the host grabs a random game from The Vault and plays it after the feature game.

The host initially picked the Roulette game by being blindfolded and spun within the vault and choosing a game randomly, but this was soon changed to picking the game with some purpose, either because of it's similarities to the featured game, the host used to love/play the game as a child, or general curiosity about the game.
Several screens of The Vault are shown after the first segment before the Roulette is chosen.
quotes: Bushido Blade
Jeff (to Dan): "You really cannot do any worse."

Phil: "Her weakness was her back, there needs to be a glowing, orange dot back there."
NBA Live '96

Dan: "We have a thrilling four-to-nothing game going on."
Dan: "How are the controls?" Reiner: "Um...atrocious."
Reiner: "I think Shaq just killed someone on the other end of the floor."

article.title: Replay – Bushido Blade
article.author: Dan Ryckert
content: Our first edition of Replay resulted in numerous requests for games weshould revisit, and our pick for this week is one that many of youmentioned. The original Bushido Blade for the PSone was a fighterunlike any other, featuring an entirely original approach to the genre.Bouts could end with one well-placed blow, and players were free toroam around its vast, oftentimes-destructible stages. Take a look belowfor our Replay of Bushido Blade. Make sure to stick around afterwardfor our first installment of Replay Roulette, in which we pull a randomgame off the Vault shelf and pop it in for a few minutes.

description: "Twisted Metal 1–4" is the name of the inaugural episode of Replay. Unlike later installments, this episode focuses on a series/genre instead of a specific game, and has no Replay Roulette. The featured games are:
Twisted Metal
Twisted Metal 2
Twisted Metal III
Critical Depth
Rogue Trip: Vacation 2012
Twisted Metal 4
This episode is hosted by Dan Ryckert and features Tim Turi, Nick Ahrens, and Andrew Reiner, all of whom take turns playing.
quotes: Reiner: "I kind of like wiener [action]."
credit_cookie: Reiner says, "I kind of like the wiener [action]."

article.title: Replay – Twisted Metal 1-4
article.author: Dan Ryckert
content: Most everyone that played Twisted Metal 1 and 2 back in the day hasfond memories of them. Their cartoonish brand of mayhem and sick senseof humor resulted in great sales numbers and an enthusiastic fanbase,before 989 Studios took over and tarnished the series' good name. Itmay have experienced a great rebirth via Twisted Metal: Black on thePS2, but the original Playstation titles by Singletrac laid thegroundwork for all subsequent car combat titles (a genre that's beensorely underrepresented in recent years).

In this new segment weutilize our extensive vault to play through each PSone Twisted Metaltitle in order, and even try out the vehicular combat experimentsSingletrac developed after losing the franchise name. Do the originalclassics hold up over a decade later? Are 3 and 4 as bad as we rememberthem being? Does Tim Turi fail miserably in his attempt to blow up theEiffel Tower? The answer to the last question is yes. Check out thevideo below to relive the 32-bit vehicular combat experience.

mainSegmentGamesAdv.title: We Wish You a Merry Christmas

article.title: Replay – Holiday Special 2015
article.author: Game Informer Staff
content: The best episodes of Replay should make you feel uncomfortable to the point that you legitimately feel sorry for everyone involved in their production. This year's Replay Holiday Special hits that note perfectly with an extended look at the Wii game, We Wish You a Merry Christmas.

Cover your ears, folks, you're going to hear us sing holiday songs, and Tim Turi never wavers from being creepily upbeat. We check out every minigame and bonus feature in this game, and walk away from this episode equally proud and depressed from our efforts to entertain.
Happy holidays to all of you, and here's hoping you stick around for another year of Replay!

mainSegmentGamesAdv.title: Home Alone 2: Lost in New York

description: Features Batman Returns and Home Alone 2: Lost in New York.

article.title: Replay Holiday Special 2014
article.author: Andrew Reiner
content: Grab a glass of eggnog and a handful of sugar cookies, everyone! The Replay crew is here to celebrate the holidays with you in the best way possible: with Batman. Yes, we decided to give Santa Claus a break this year, and play the Christmas-themed Batman Returns instead. We battle our way through waves of clowns (why are they clowns?) and square off against Catwoman, all to deliver holiday cheer!
We hope that you and all of your loved ones have a great holiday season. We'll see you in the New Year (and in new Super Replay)!

external_links.title: Bonus Replay – Strider (Guests: Arj Barker And Louis Katz)
Bonus Replay – Strider (Guest: Arj Barker And Louis Katz)

article.title: Bonus Replay – Strider (Guests: Arj Barker And Louis Katz)
article.author: Kyle Hilliard
content: In this special bonus episode of Replay, we take a look at the original incarnation of Strider on the NES. Myself and Ben Reeves are joined by comedians Arj Barker and Louis Katz as we travel the world and discuss the differences between Strider's interpretation and the real world version of Australia, where Arj Barker lives half the year.

Both Arj Barker and Louis Katz are accomplished comedians releasing assorted specials and appearing on Comedy Central as well as late night night shows such as Jimmy Fallon's. You may also recognize Arj Barker from the HBO comedy, Flight of the Conchords where he played the titular duo's American, pawn shop owning friend Dave. For more on Louis Katz, you can check out his website. For more on Arj Barker, you can check out his website.

mainSegmentGamesAdv.title: ToeJam & Earl in Panic on Funkotron

external_links.title: Replay – ToeJam & Earl 2 (Special Guest: Riff Raff)

article.title: Replay – ToeJam & Earl 2 (Special Guest: Riff Raff)
article.author: Dan Ryckert
content: We've listened to Tim rave about the soundtrack for ToeJam & Earl for years, and figured it was about time to bring out the Genesis to play it for ourselves. When some antagonistic Earthlings stow away as the two aliens head back to Funkotron, it's up to the funky duo to track them down and send them back home.
Watch below to see Andrew Reiner, Tim Turi, me, and special guest Riff Raff check out the Genesis title, followed by the Replay crew receiving their first game pitch from Jody Highroller himself.

description: Features Daze Before Christmas for Genesis and Mario Party 6 for GameCube.

article.title: Replay Holiday Special 2013
article.author: Andrew Reiner
content: Happy holidays, Replay community! The Game Informer staff tracked down an odd little game crammed to capacity with holiday cheer.In Funcom and Sunsoft's Days Before Christmas, Santa bounds across perilous pits to rescue woodland elves trapped in presents, and to reclaim his prized star collection. In a strange twist, he also transforms into a hideous Anti-Claus, using a bag full of toys as a weapon to beat the life out of mice in scuba gear. Yes, this game is a real trip.
Our second segment begins with an unexpected visit from a Replay fan, who hands us a gift that we didn't want, but you surely did. If this guest ever shows his face again, we're taking him down.

article.title: Replay Halloween Special 2013
article.author: Andrew Reiner
content: Before you head outside to hunt down a mountain of free candy, spend a half hour with the Game Informer crew in this Replay Halloween Special. We take a look at four games in this episode, all set within Namco's Splatterhouse series. Tim Turi and Jason Oestreicher work their way through each game, showing us just how difficult they are, and how much the Terror Mask changes in each game. Our journey begins original arcade release and concludes with an oddity not many people know about. We hope you all have a great Halloween, and end up getting a great assortment of candy that is mostly free of that crappy taffy in orange and black wrappers.

article.title: Replay – Mutant League Football
article.author: Matt Helgeson
content: We take a look back at EA's grisly gridiron classic.

By now, you may have heard the news that Michael Mendheim, the creator of Mutant League Football, is launching a Kickstarter to create a spiritual successor to the Genesis-era cult classic. To celebrate, host Andy Reiner welcomes Matt Helgeson, Ben Reeves, Kim Wallace, and Jason Oestreicher to the Replay studio to see how the original holds up. The results are a bit ugly at times – to hilarious results. Also, without spoiling anything, in the Replay Roulette segment, Ben Reeves pulls off one of the most pathetic "feats" in Replay history, to Kim's chagrin.

external_links.title: Replay – Punch-Out!! Stress Test: Joe Vs. Tyson – Episode 2
Stress Test – Joe vs Tyson – Episode 1

article.title: Replay – Punch-Out!! Stress Test: Joe Vs. Tyson – Episode 2
article.author: Joe Juba
content: Earlier this year, I watched my co-worker Dan try to defeat Mike Tyson in Punch-Out!!. He failed miserably for three straight hours. Near the end of his attempt, I made a bold claim: Dan's story was just a prologue to a better (and shorter) video featuring me effortlessly beating Iron Mike. The time has finally come to back up my bravado.

While I try to shame Dan on the gameplay front, the accompanying commentary from Andrew Reiner and Jeff Marchiafava shame him on several personal and professional levels.  Dan sits in also, but his testimony does more to incriminate than defend himself.
Watch the drama unfold in the video below:

external_links.title: Replay – Punch-Out!! Stress Test: Dan Vs. Tyson Part III
Stress Test – Dan vs Tyson in Punch–Out

article.title: Replay – Punch-Out!! Stress Test: Dan Vs. Tyson Part III
article.author: Dan Ryckert
content: In my entire gaming history, one accomplishment has eluded me more than any other. I've completed hundreds upon hundreds of games and stood victorious over insanely difficult boss battles, but one man has annihilated me every time I've encountered him. Mike Tyson's Punch-Out!! is one of my top ten games of all time, but it's one I've never beat. In 2013, it's time to get serious about getting this monkey off my back.
Click below to witness my quest to defeat my biggest gaming nightmare.

mainSegmentGamesAdv.title: Santa Claus is Comin' to Town

description: Features Santa Claus is Comin' To Town! for Wii. The Replay Roulette is The Grinch for Dreamcast.

article.title: Replay Holiday Special
article.author: Andrew Reiner
content: 'Tis the season for crappy holiday gaming. Scattered within the thousands of games in Game Informer's vault, we found two that celebrate the holiday season. Now that Wii U is on store shelves, we can officially dive into Wii's library for Replay episodes. Outside of Tim breaking the rules of the spacetime continuum with his rogue Super Smash Bros. Brawl Replay episode, our first sanctioned Wii game is Santa Claus is Comin' to Town! Our Roulette is equally as season-appropriate. Enjoy the episode, folks! And happy holidays!

description: In short: a portal into the insanity that is the mind of Ben Reeves. By Episode 8 of the Sonic the Hedgehog Super Replay Ben has lost all memory of this episode. The crew states that Season 4 of Replay may have a new version of Ben Reeves' insanity.
One full stand alone episode was produced as Reevesplay: Silent Bomber. A second episode was used with X-Men 2: Clone Wars as a second segment to the Extermination replay.

article.title: This Isn't Replay: It's Reevesplay!
article.author: Ben Reeves
content: Playing games by myself is no strange thing, but I don't usually record it. Now I have!

This has been a long time coming. I apologize for the wait. Check out the video of me playing the little talked about PSOne title Silent Bomber below. It's like watching a recording of a guy who's playing a game by himself.

episodeTitle: Super Readplay: Gears of War: Anvil Gate

description: Super Readplay is a gag episode of Replay that features Dan Ryckert reading the prologue of the book Gears of War: Anvil Gate based in the Gears of War universe. Although the episode is listed in the Replay hub, it is not an official episode, but is counted toward the 100th episode claimed in the Super Mario 64 Replay.
The official page for the episode lists it as 1 of 82.
trivia: The song looping in the background is "Kepora Gebora's Theme" from The Legend of Zelda: Ocarina of Time Original Soundtrack.

external_links.title: Super Readplay: Gears of War: Anvil Gate

article.title: Super Readplay – Gears of War: Anvil Gate
article.author: Dan Ryckert
content: You may already be familiar with our Super Replay series, in which we play through the entirety of some of the all-time greatest games. So far, we've presented you with the iconic Legend of Zelda: Link to the Past and Resident Evil 2. While we are a gaming-focused website, we have respect for all of the arts. So why should we deprive you of the all-time greats from other entertainment mediums? My boss (Reiner) told me that reading great literature is also a sometimes-worthwhile pursuit. He assured me that Gears of War: Anvil Gate is widely considered one of the all-time great examples of the written word.
Because of his enthusiasm for this particular work, I didn't protest when he asked me to begin a Super Readplay of Gears of War: Anvil Gate. You can watch part 1 of 82 below. Enjoy.

description: Winter Games is an unofficial episode of Replay that was posted to Game Informer editor Matt Bertz's site blog on February 25, 2010 under the title A Supposedly Fun Thing I'll Never Do Again (a reference to a collection of nonfiction writing by David Foster Wallace). The episode is hosted by Matt Bertz and features Replay regulars Tim Turi, Andrew Reiner, and Dan Ryckert.

Bertz describes Winter Games as "the worst game I ever had the misfortune of owning." As explained in the blog post, the game was an impulse purchase from a moment in Bertz's childhood when his parents allowed him to pick out one video game to buy at a game store. He settled on Winter Games because of its "Miami Vice cover art."
The episode is not featured in the Replay hub.
